The fish is always fresh and the service friendly
I always get the Chirashi bowl. I went around and tried other places, but for the money, this place is overall the best bargain for the amount of food.
The gf gets the 8pc hamachi and the alaska roll i believe. She kills it all the time.

the sushi chef is friendly, always done to drink with a customer.

I recommend anyone who is looking to eat sushi to try this place. great food, great prices.
author: Andi I.

description:
Looking for a laid-back neighborhood restaurant? This is the right place. Located on a quiet block in the Richmond District, this is my sleeper pick for a nice, quiet (perhaps romantic) dinner. The menu is pretty extensive with its appetizers, sushi/sashimi choices, dinners (solo or combinations), and noodles (udon, soba, and ramen). The daily specials are located on a chalkboard behind the sushi chefs and many sounded very tempting, especially the Lobster Handroll. We shared the following: 
Appetizers 
Agedashi tofu - Deep fried tofu pillows topped with diced green onion and shredded nori strips; a small bowl of tempura sauce is served for dipping (like that it's separate so that the tofu is not soggy). 
Crab salad - A mixture of some spinach and wild greens with shredded snow or king crab. Again, the salad dressing is served in separate small dishes, one with a vinegar soy and the other a sesame dressing. 
Sushi 
Northern Roll - Eel, avocado, and snow or king crab. (6 pcs.) 
Space Roll - Tuna (Maguro), Hamachi (yellowtail), and eel ( 6 pcs.) 
Nigiri Unagi - Eel ( 2 pcs.) 
Dinner Combination 
Tempura and Beef Sukiyaki - My favorite entree here is the Beef Sukiyaki which feature thinly sliced beef in a sweet soy based broth with tofu, clear rice noodles, fresh mushrooms, bamboo shoot slices, and shredded green onion. The tempura includes two prawns, one yam, one zucchini, one eggplant, one mushroom, and one Japanese pumpkin, I believe. 
The complete dinners come with a salad of rice noodles, ham, and cucumber in a light mayonnaise and bowl of miso soup. 
Dinner came to $57.00 before tip, pretty reasonable the amount of food we ordered. Having a light lunch, I was not shy in making the food mysteriously disappear. The customers varied from singles on the sushi bar, young couples and large families (bumped into a Chinatown restaurant-owning family tonight here) dining at the tables. Normally, I wouldn't encourage eating here because of the notorious Richmond District parking reputation, but the trick is arriving shortly before 8 pm and finding a designated bus stop. For a late dinner, this is definitely one find to tuck in your pocket. Also, remember to try the wrapped chocolate that comes with the bill. This will add to the sweet taste in your mouth after you've eaten here.
author: Mike C.

description:
for a spontaneous dinner, this place was a great choice! the sushi bar is lighted to over shine the main area, with decent seating, and a side area with a..pretty loud party table tonight.  It's a casual, romantic setting ready for some good food.

I ordered the tenzaru soba ( i LOVE cold soba!), the seaweed salad. The beau ordered tako nigiri and a combo of teriyaki and a side of tuna sashimi. It was brought out very timely, so we were very pleased. The tempura vegetables and prawn had a sweet crisp batter I dipped into the noodle sauce, since...i don't know if they provided tempura sauce. It was great though! The tako had a dip of wasabi in it, which freaked me out since I don't like wasabi.............................(yea i know..)

The only thing off was that we ordered the Space Roll, sounded delightful, but it never came out. We looked on the bill, turns out the waiter never wrote it down. There was plenty on the table to fill us up so we didn't say anything, and as long as they didn't charge it for it, it's all good!

We didn't order drinks or anything. It was one of those meals that I truly enjoyed to even think about anything else to could be added to it, except tempura sauce? ahahah. Overall, meal was great, service was good, atmosphere was cheerful and friendly, and it wasn't too cold or too hot in the restaurant (which is oddly very important to me). I come here again, definitely.
author: Anna H.

description:
I came here for lunch w/my niece, who's a regular customer.  I haven't tried this place in many years.
We shared one of my favorite dishes, the noodle salad, $4, plenty to share for 2.  It's a clear rice noodle dish with mayonnaise dressing and bits of fish cake.  Still tastes as good as I remembered.
Their lunch specials are about $10 and I had the sushii special which came with a miso soup. The sushi was good, but not memorable for me.  6 pieces of CA roll, maguro, salmon.

Service is good and Aki, the owner, still works the sushi bar and his ex, Chico runs the rest of the restaurant with their staff. It's a small place with about 7 tables and seating for 6-7 at the sushi bar.  A nice neighborhood restaurant but parking can be challenging especially in the evenings.
author: Ry T.

description:
I went there for the first time last Friday night, 5/2/14.  I enjoyed the food and service.  A waitress quickly served me a complementary pot of hot tea.  I ordered 2 satisfying dishes: spider roll and adegashi tofu.  The 8-piece spider roll has 1/2 fried soft shell crab, snow crab here and there, 1/2 asparagus stalk, Chinese broccoli, fish eggs, 2 thin sticks of pickled carrot, 1 thin stick of cucumber.  I found the Chinese broccoli a pleasant surprise.  I did not expect it but was pleased to eat my leafy green.  If you enjoy tofu like me, the adegashi tofu could be a 10/10 if they serve the broth on the side instead of on the tofu.  The tempura tofu became a bit soggy once soaked in the broth, but it was still a 9/10 for me.

Beside the good food and service, I found the restaurant very small, cramped, and dirty.  Dated and discolored carpet.  Tiny restrooms with not-so-clean smell.  They should VACUUM at least twice daily, especially btw lunch and dinner.  They should repaint the interior walls and remodel.  Despite good food and service, I will not take my husband or friends here due to the lack of ambiance and cleanliness.  Pricing wise, it's similar to Yuubi, Ebisu, Chin, ...  Yuubi and Ebisu are much cleaner than Tanuki.
author: G D.

description:
My favorite sushi place is Murasaki, but I have become friends with the owner, so i'm sure i'm biased.  I don't really go anywhere else for sushi.  However, I came here with family after a Japanese friend recommended it.  

The great thing i found was a wide variety of choices!  Everything was good, but I was especially happy to find tenzaru soba (cold buckwheat noodles with tempura). i'm a noodle-slurping MF when i find good noodles.

also a nice healthy portion of karaage - japanese chicken nuggets...

the sushi was good too (sorry sasaki-san)
author: tom p.

description: I have NEVER had a worse experience at any "Japanese" resaturant. We got the bum's rush from the moment we sat down , hurry and order so we can turn over the table. The large green salad is definitely not large and somewhat tasteless, wilted lettuce leaves with a few shreds of orange & red peppers, dressing is sparse and not real tasty. Miso soup is ok , $2 on the menu $4 on your bill. Rolls are not so fresh tasting and overpriced. Tempura vegetables were soggy , not crunchy at all. Teriyaki chicken will remind you more of a Chinese restaurant than any Japanese recipe. With sooooooo many great options in San Francisco, skip this one for sure.
author: Mike L.

description:
Let's take a stab at Yelping this place in the form of a haiku...

Sushi oishii
In English that's delicious
No doubt finest fish


Probably shouldn't quit my day job, eh?
author: Alan N.

description:
Sushi is terrific here. My Mom and I enjoyed the crunchy roll, spider roll (soft shell crab) and bento box with beef teriyaki, chicken wing, tempura, noodles with a mayo mixture and rice. Very authentic, small- but cozy, very clean restaurant. 

Parking is difficult, so I park on Clement. 

Cheers!
author: Nathalie C.

description: Self confessed sushi snob. Good spot. Get the uni shot. You will not regret it.
author: Ryan M.

description:
This is my first review, but I feel like this one MUST be my first.  I have been a loyal customer to Tanuki since i was 4 years old! My first experience at a sushi bar has been at Tanuki and many holidays and late nights have been spent there. Tanuki has been, and will be my favorite japanese restaurant EVER.

It is owned and run by an old japanese couple.  The sushi chef and owner, Aki-san, is probably the nicest guy i have ever met.  If you decide to sit at the bar he will randomly give you free mini-dishes like natto or mini sushi wrapped with lettuce rather than seaweed.  Aside from the friendly but quite atmosphere of the store, the food is amazing.  My family is half-japanese so I'd like to say I do have some experience in japanese food.  My favorite dish would be the sukiyaki.  It can be quite a lot so I suggest sharing it with another person.  They also have a smaller version if you decide to order a combo with sukiyaki.  I also enjoy the Chicken kara-age and their tempura.  A word of warning though, the food fills you up surprisingly fast, so watch what you order!

If you are yelping this restaurant right now definitely go check it out! It's definitely a restaurant worth going to. oh! and don't hesitate to make friends with aki-san! It never hurts to have a sushi-chef friend.
author: Kyle G.

description:
I LOOOOOVE their oyster shots and uni shots. SO GOOD! It's sometimes hard to get all the uni out of the little shot glass, but it's still delicious. 

The sushi chefs are friendly and nice. It's a little more pricey than other japanese restuarants but I don't mind at all. Rolls are pricey too but delicious! 

The noodle dish was something I keep forgetting I like. I take a bite and it's like... oh ok... wait... this is delicious! 

The white tuna sashimi I had was fresh and they were huge slices. Delish! 

I just want some more of those shots! YUM!
author: Jeannie L.

description:
given San Francisco's vast Asian influence, I always find myself curiously trying to uncover that secret & amazing japanese hole-in-the-wall but always end up sitting directly in front of Aki-San, devouring Tanuki's deliciously silky, unbelievably fresh nigiri. Through my extensive travels, I can safely say that not much compares. This is my go-to neighborhood sushi joint. No thrills, just a very traditional, inviting place to eat the best sushi around. Not gonna begin to name specific sushi selections because it's all good. Just ask Aki-San what's fresh that day; He will never steer you wrong. 

Bonus: little TV above the sushi bar for your Giants viewing pleasure...
author: Max R.

description:
I absolutely love this place for their lunch specials.  

Try the Sushi Special which gives you 3 piece California Roll/3 piece Maguro/Avocado Roll with other assorted nigiri sushi.  It is very fresh fish, satisfying, and very reasonably priced at $10.95.  

They also have great Bento Box specials sor about $12.95.  

Definitely worth checking out for a nice Japanese lunch meal!
author: Eric G.

description:
This is our neighborhood sushi spot. We walk here for lunch/dinner several times a month. Love the good sushi and relaxed atmosphere.

The rolls, sashimi, and nigiris are made well and the friendly chefs are generous with their portions. Usually, I'll order an udon for my two young children to share, and it is delicious.

I prefer to sit in the room which is next to the bar (seems like the service and sushi end up being better) than sitting in the room off to the side. Nevertheless, this is a solid, gem of a restaurant. It can be comfortably busy, but not out-the-door busy. I actually hesitated to write this review for fear that it will be discovered and we'll end up having to wait for a table.

The service is good, but I just have to add that, in particular, the young gentleman there is an excellent server.
author: Kimbalee W.

description:
Alas I did not get the sunomono.  But I did get the mirugai and the awebi.  Awebi is abalone and this was the first time I've ever had it.  The texture is more firm than clam.  Slightly crunchy.  More crunchy than chewy.  Sweet.  With slightly firmer/crunchier around the edge.  

Lou and I sat at the bar.  This is our new thing.  We're going to sit at the bar because I can't stand to look at him the whole dinner.  And because I get uncomfortable when someone watches me eat.  I think I'm well on my way to getting a serious eating disorder.

The sushi bar glass case was chock full of fish and shellfish.  It was impressively varied and colorful.  I saw the mirugai hiding behind the abalone, different tuna, lobster, and at the very very end, the elusive uni.  

We ordered: 
shiro maguro - melt in your mouth goodness.  Do not accept escolar/butter fish as a substituted, it should be albacore.
uni - I will arm wrestle anyone for the last piece of uni.  This was the best taste/texture/firmness uni that I've had.  It was chilled and firm.
mirugai - alas, it was already prepared so I did not get to see the chef do rude things to peen-peen.
abalone - all things considered, I'd chose another uni over this though it was very good.  it's just not my thing.
saba - green onion does wonders for this fishy fishy.  
aji - new favorite mackeral-thing.  grated ginger!
miso soup - tofu and seaweed was plentiful.

The couple next to us got this foil steamed thing that looked like an alien-repelling helmet.  But I think it was a popular thing because several more people got it.  I wanted to do an uni shot but Lou wanted just a piece of uni.  Like I said, arm wrestle.  

The more I eat sushi, the more I am disenchanted by jive-ass rolls.  They never come out as pretty as the pictures.  This place had terrific fish, terrific service, and was the perfect thing on a foggy monday night.  I hate mondays but Tanuki makes it something to look forward to.

--------------------
UPDATE 10/15/09

I am not proud to say that I cheat on my BF with food.  Yes.  It's true.  I would rather have a nice nigiri snack/dinner by myself than eat it with him.  I would rather have fish than toast.  I like it raw.  Cherry cherry boom boom.  

My BF informed me that he was going to be late coming home, 7pm or later.  I was home at 5pm.  What did I do?  I took the bus to Tanuki.  I ordered the seafood sunomono, 1 aji, 1 ika, and 2 uni.  I had 4 beautiful pieces of uni prostrating at my fingers, slipping down my throat and putting a cheese-eating grin on my face from ear to ear.  Smiling causes wrinkles but I didn't care.  I've got some uni in my mouth, leave me alone.

The seafood sunomono was briming with all sorts of seafood.  There was dungeness crab, ebi, ika, tako, white fish, tuna, salmon, so much stuff.  I like the cucumbers at Kazu better because at Tanuki, there was so much seafood, the cucumbers were a mere formality.  Practically a garnish.  And it was $6.50.  

Sushi Chef, will you marry me?  I've never been the settling down type, but you make me never want to leave my counter seat.
author: Christina C.

description:
Love! We came here for lunch on a Sunday and were pleasantly surprised. I got the lunch combination of sukiyaki and sashimi. For $14 I got a big bowl of sukiyaki and rice, salad, soup, and 7 slices of tuna sashimi. Insane! We also ordered 8 of sushi sashimi and that somehow cost more than the combination.

The beef sukiyaki was really tasty though didn't come with too much beef. The soup was good and very hot which was perfect for a cloudy day and the salad was tasty, too. The fish was fresh and really tasty. Service was excellent, too.

I would absolutely come back here.
author: Lisa C.

description: If you're craving sushi or Japanese food, try Tanuki. The menu selection is quite impressive and the rolls aren't terribly expensive. I ended up getting the pork katsu donburi and my friend got some rolls. My donburi was really filling and quite a large portion. It's not terribly noisy too so you can have a conversation with your dining partner. It's a good place to catch up.
author: Amy J.

description:
By far, the FRESHEST sashimi in the Richmond District.  A little pricey, but worth it!
I can't get enough of their noodle salad...
author: D R.

description:
I have been on a sushi hiatus for some unknown reason and was really excited to finally get back on the sushi saddle.  Yelp really screwed me on this one.  As my dining companion eloquently put it, "Tanuki?  More like Tapukey."

I was hoping this place was going to be good, let me tell you 10 reasons it's not: 
-The fish was waaaay not fresh
-The rice was flavorless
-The rolls were wrapped horribly
-Shell in my uni shot
-The $14 house special was tiny
-It's unreasonably expensive (see above)
-The tomatoes in the salad were basically macerated, uck
-The pitcher of beer is $20, giving you 3.5 beers at best...it's a better deal just to buy individual beers
-I had bones in my sushi and they didn't care
-The waiter totally put his hand on my food and didn't say anything

There is no reason to come back here.
author: Pouria Y.

description:
Long story short: Food is absolutely amazingly fantastic, out-of-this-world fresh and delicious, but even better are the wonderful people who work there.

Tonight Tanuki has proven itself to be a restaurant of not only simply outstanding quality, but of incredible patience.

Because two strangers wandered in off the street-
 1) five minutes to closing
 2) on a Tuesday night
 3) ordered four sushi rolls
and 4) ate every last grain of rice.

And not once were my companion and I complained to, or rushed in any way to hurry up, and kindly get out- not in the slightest,

Once we walked in, we were welcomed warmly by the wait staff and by the lone sushi chef.  

We were immediately seated, and although we were advised that we would be the last order, the waitress- who was beautiful, everyone there was- hastily with sincerity added that my companion and I should not feel rushed, please take as much time as we needed.  And though my companion and I were quick to make our decisions on our order, since we were both sympathetic to the food service industry, we were again urged by the waitress not to feel rushed once the food was brought to us.

The Rainbow Roll was one of the freshest and most delectable I'd ever tasted- I was sad to see it go.

I loved the miso soup with little mushrooms in it, the flavors of the soup were comforting and harmonious.

As my companion and I sat and ate, the staff began some of the night's clean-up duties.  The Sushi Chef was meticulous about clearing away and cleaning his station.  He handled everything with care, and executed each dish we'd ordered with precision and incredible skill and talent.

In every way, I am incredibly impressed with Tanuki Restaurant, on California between sixth and seventh.  I absolutely cannot wait to go back again.

Thank you, especially, to the staff there who above everything else were patient, courteous, clean, considerate, and incredibly professional and warm towards two hungry late-wandering strangers who found their way to Sushi Nirvana this Tuesday night.
author: Marisa D.

description:
Okay...you got me!!!

Started with edamame, decent portion for over three bucks.  

Sashimi combo fish of 20 slices for $28.  Fresh tuna, red snapper, white tuna, yellowtail, surf clam and mackerel.  *droool* High quality, great presentation and just delicious.  

Spicy scallop handroll--thank you for having such fresh scallops and not cooking the scallops!  Very delicious indeed.

Their rolls are of decent size too without overdressing it with sauce, and of course top quality fish too.  

Decent list of sake...although it's not on the menu. Look at the placard on the table.  lol oops.  I ended up with a small Asahi, and some gen mai cha...yum.  

Service = excellent.  Very friendly.  They try to be efficient, even if they are super busy.  

Decor = very simple, not dim, and just clean.

Parking = typical inner Richmond drivel, so plan ahead.

Prices = good for the quality!!! 

Total bill came to under $58.00 for two, after taxes.  Trust me... it was worth it.  *drools in anticipation of next time*

And next time...I'm trying all the other stuff! :-P *snorts like a piggie-wiggie*  Might be a great place for out-of-town guests or some other special occasion...:D

Oh yeah, and points for having Tanuki on their chopsticks' wrapper...cute!
author: Fannie S.

description: The food is always good. I don't go as often as my wife since she works in the neighborhood, but I always like it. The staff is nice too.
author: Dave B.

description: OMG - it's a totally different restaurant. And I don't mean that in a good way. Last meal I had there was inedible. Service is horrible, food is horrible, and it's expensive!
author: L. M.

description:
More like a 4.5

Their uni shot went down quite well - which was a huge surprise to me. As I find that uni usually has that salty seawater taste and I dislike it.

Their sashimi combo plates are always fresh. I suggest sitting at the sushi bar as the sushi chefs seem to be nicer to people there. I sat at the sushi bar once, and the chefs gave me a free dish of their eggplant with miso sauce. They were super nice and attentive. I even got toro on my sushi plate! 

Fresh sushi, decent price - i will definately come again!
author: Amy T.

description: It's hard to find a standout sushi restaurant in the Richmond... 1, its everywhere... 2, it's all cheap... This is one of the freshest place I could find around my neighborhood... everything other place seems to smell overly fishy... but I guess you get what you pay for... the staff was super friendly, I thought it was worth a mention...
author: Nathan D.

description:
I love Tanuki. I've eaten here since I was like 7 or 8 years old and the food, for the most part, have tasted consistently good. When I come here, I always order the Noodle Salad. (To me, it's the tastier version of cole slaw, and I don't like eating cole slaw. Yeah I'm weird.) My mom is a big fan of their green salad, mainly because of the dressing that they use. Their salad bowl portion is decently sized too, usually to the point where my mom has to split it with my dad, who isn't a huge fan of salad. 

Their sushi, for the most part, has never disappointed me. They use real ingredients to make their California roll, not imitation shrimp. I usually order their Okame udon because it tastes so clean. Some Japanese places that I go to, their vegetarian udon has too much stuff in it. This place does it perfectly, with few slices of fish cake, mushrooms, beans and green onions. My parents usually order their salmon teriyaki or the beef donburi. I will admit, the beef donburi tastes pretty good too.

They don't allow reservations unless you have a huge party (i.e. 6 or more). They get busy on weekend nights starting at 7pm. Parking can be a pain at times. Service in general is decent but the waiters/waitresses are pretty busy, so if you need something you'll need to flag them down. Their food is not cheap in comparison to other Japanese restaurants, but I think it's a nice place to go once in a while if you're in a mood for Japanese food. It's better than SF's J-Town's Japanese food.
author: Selina T.

description: Highly suggest walking down the street.  The toro was badly cut, but...when five drunk men started using the c word and talking about strippers in front of my family...I was the one to have to speak up.   Then I was asked to leave not them.  Poor management.
author: Chris S.

description:
Ordered take out, when I got there, they charged $7 more than what was advertised on their online menu. Manager didn't give a rats ass about the discrepancy. 

Buyer beware.
author: R V.

description:
Tanuki is the most authentic Sushi bar in the neighborhood. The owners are a Japanese couple, a rare find in the plethora of Chinese and Korean owned places around. The sushi chef/owner is masterful with knife, slicing perfectly even, ocean fresh seafood. He adds just enough seasoning, never overpowering the fish. Service is fast and attentive, and they keep a TV behind the bar if you want to watch the game.

You get a really nice free app, not edamame or pickles. First time in it was monkfish liver over greens. Something I never would have ordered, and what a shame that would have been.Delicious!  The only drawback here, and the reason for the lack of a fifth star, is the inflated beer prices. It is one of the highest in the neighborhood. My wallet usually takes a good pounding here, but I am never shy to order at my whimsy.
author: Scott B.

description: I completely love this place!  The sushi bar is small and quaint, with a tv that plays all sport casting!  I am not a fan of mixing tv and food but it works here.
author: Lane K.

description:
Very nice little restaurant along the street. Pleasant waitresses and welcoming sushi chef to make you feel comfortable. 

Being a backpacker, this place was a little bit high on our expenditure - but it was worth it. My friend and I ordered their udons and their sashimi together with their sake selection. 

My take:

Udon - 9/10, noodle was soft and chewy, authentic enough. Soup base was great, very savoury but might a bit salty towards the end of the meal. Generally, it was an excellent bowl of udon(beef and tempura). Delicious!!!

Sashimi - 6/10, coming from an asian country myself, I have definitely tasted better grades of sashimi. Only tried the salmon sashimi. Portions and cuts were thick and nice, comfortable portions. But texture wise, it was a tad mushy for me, just a little bit, and it was on the average side. Like I said again, being an asian, I have definitely tried better ones back home. Thumbs up though for the sashimi. Pretty good for an outlet in the states. 12 moderately thick slices of sashimi for 17 bucks(a rip off to me)

Sake/Shochu - 7/10, alcoholic japanese wine, once again, tried better and stronger ones myself. But they serve a pretty good variety(about 10?) of different sakes and shochu. Pretty reasonable prices for their size. 300ml of sake for 8 dollars, and a glass of shochu(premium barley) for the same price.

Didnt get to try their sushi though, but the sashimi and the sake complimented the meal well enough. 

On a whole, 2 bowls of udon, 1 plate of salmon sashimi(12 moderately thick slices) and 1 bottle of sake and 1 glass of shochu - a simple meal costs us about 30 per person.

Will recommend it for those who are willing to splurge abit for japanese fare. Hurts on backpackers' wallets though.
author: Joash Y.

description:
Oishii desu nee! 

There really are Japanese sushi chefs here, and Japanese regulars who drop in.  I guess I could call myself a regular now, even though I'm not Japanese myself.  It's just around the corner, and when we just want to get out of the house and eat, the staff always welcome us.  

The noodle salad that they serve with every order is delicious, and we actually look forward to it.  Whether you order sushi in its myriad forms, or one of the tempura dishes, it's all good.  The tofu in the soup is like custard.  

An order of chicken teriyaki, an order of tempura, and a serving of green tea ice cream, along with the complimentary noodle salad and green tea, cost us just under $30.  

We've been here before, and we'll be here again.  Kanpai!
author: David D.

description: I heart Tanuki. The animal and this establishment. Always friendly, good prices, tasty fish, yummy specials, and nice servers. Itadakimasu!
author: Krystyna B.

description:
If you want good Japanese food, come to Tanuki.  This place is owned and operated by a Japanese husband and wife (a rarity, am I right?)  The sushi chef is the husband , and in the kitchen the wife is cooking the food.  

My family has been coming here for years, and the wife always comes out of the kitchen to greet my parents when we eat here.  If you become regulars here, they'll definitely remember you and give you extra perks.

My favorite thing to eat at Tanuki is the noodle salad.  The noodle salad only comes with dinners, so if you don't order dinner, make sure to order it on the side.  That being said, I always order dinner, so I don't know too much about the sushi.  Although, my brother always orders sushi, so the raw fish must be good.  I usually stick to the chicken teriyaki.  Please note, the chicken teriyaki here is fried, not the usual grilled chicken though they do serve the grilled chicken teriyaki.  The Hamachi Kama is also exceptionally good; always nice and fatty.

Tanuki serves all your standard generic Japanese food, but they make it authentically, the right way.  I'd recommend ordering something off of the "specials" board, you won't be disappointed.

The prices are a little bit expensive, but the portions are large and the flavors are always on point.
author: Anthony N.

description:
Some say that Sunday is the worst day for sushi but take me to Tanuki any Sunday for supper because I am in love with the ambiance here. 

While their sashimi combo was ok, and their maguro tataki was a bit bland--but their seafood sunomono (the crab!!), tanuki roll (eel, shrimp tempura, eggplant and avocado--yum!) and their great service is enough to keep me coming back. 

So come on over, grab a window seat, sip some tea and watch the light dissipate in the quiet calm that is California Street.
author: Faffy L.

description:
We had dinner here last night and although nothing stood out especially or jumped out at us, everything was pretty tasty, the service was fast and friendly, we found easy parking right around the corner and I left full and happy. 
I loved the seafood salad most of all.
I'll be back
author: Nilu r.

description:
I had the pleasure to go to Tanuki with a regular. The chef provided us with copious amounts of fresh and delicious  sashimi. From what I could remember we had the oyster shooter, uni shooter, steamed egg, tuna toro, hamachi toro, white tuna, scallops, sweet shrimp, uni, lobster hand roll, and much more. 

I absolutely loved the uni and oyster shots, as well as the steamed egg.
author: Amy K.

description: I've been to this place since I was a teen and had the pleasure to share it with friends and now my family. The owner even recognizes me after all these years! He's great! We love sitting at the bar so we can toast sake shots with him and his sous-chef. The most memorable dinner was the time he made tiny uni and unagi sushi for our then 2.5 yrs old son, and he gobbled that up! We always have a blast there with the owner as we dine and sometimes watch the game that's on...be it baseball, football, etc!
author: Yen B.

description:
We had a fabulous lunch here yesterday.  I told my partner that, if memory serves me right, I ate my very first sushi dinner here many, many years ago.  And even though I have not been back in a very long while, it's not been for lack of trying, since the opening hour for dinner here is a little later than when we usually like to start our dinner out.  However, since we were in  the area yesterday, my partner suggested we walk past to see if they're open for lunch.  I went along, full of skepticism.  Boy, was I so happily wrong!  We got there 20 minutes before the end of their lunch service but there were still about 1/2 dozen tables occupied and we were greeted warmly by 2 of their staff so we knew we can have our meal without feeling rushed.  I ordered their 4 (!) item bento lunch special: Tonkatsu, Sashimi, Tempura and what would have been Chicken Teriyaki but I was given a choice of whether I wanted the chicken grilled or fried and of course I have to go for fried.  All for $12!!   My favorite items are the fried chicken and the Tempura, both fried perfectly, the tempura batter was used lightly and has just the right amount of seasoning.  I also loved their noodle salad that came with the bento, leaving such a big impression with such a tiny portion.  Wish i can get that at other restaurants' bento offerings, sigh...  My partner ordered their 12 piece Sashimi plate and the slices were very generously cut and so fresh.

I don''t know when I can make it back, but I'll look forward to that day...
author: Yvette F.

description: What a big difference from Sake Zone!  Man was I missing out haha.  The salmon sashimi was so fresh that it practically melted in my mouth!   The lobster hand roll was really good as well. The spicy hamachi roll was good but it wasn't as spicy as I would like it to be.  Service was superb. I will be back again!
author: Christy A.

description:
Sooo delicious!!  Tanuki is another izakaya style restaurant like Oyaji.  They both have their distinct style, but boy am i glad that we found out this place.  

My bf and I were supposed to go omakase with Tekka, but unfortunately it was closed, so we were pondering around and found Tanuki!  I remembered that one of my coworkers was talking about a restaurant on 6th and California where they served Lobster roll and oyster shot.... My bf and I just saw the outside of Tanuki and thought it look pretty solid for a japanese restaurant and decided to try it out.  Little did we know we actually went into the restaurant my coworker recommended!

So we ordered the Lobster handroll.  OMG that thing is TO DIE FOR!!!  so sweet and the sauce accentuated the sweetness of the lobster... mmmmm sooo yummy.  And then we went all out and ordered the sashimi 20 slices combo, kompachi nigiri (not on the menu but I overheard that they have it), saba sashimi, oyster shot, uni shot, toro nigiri.. (yea yea i know we eat lots for 2 people...)  OMG they were ALL super delicious!  They didn't go cheap on the sashimi combo and gave us some of the unusual stuff like aji, bonito, mirugai, and scallops.  The kompachi, mmmmmm, is soooo extremely delicious and fresh!  The saba is best saba i ever tasted!  and the oyster and uni shot... you gotta try that out!!  

Anyway, just go there and try it out.  The price is reasonable, great and cool chef, cool environment, GREAT FOOD, FRESH FISH, and we had an awesome time!!!
author: Gigi T.

description:
I have always liked and recommended Tanuki. However last night we went for an early dinner on the way to a movie. The service was awful even though we were the only table seated. After waiting 20 minutes to get our order taken, finally got the dinner. Nigiri Sushi dinner was a total disappointment. The fish looked tired, did not have the bright sheen and tasted as tired. The sake which we like hot was barely warm.
I think it will be a while before we go back or praise Tanuki.
author: Yasmine S.

description:
This is the real deal.  I lived in Japan for years, eating everywhere from 100-yen conveyor-belt sushi places to wonderful, expensive holes in the wall, and I'm always apprehensive going out to eat sushi here in the U.S. because it tends to be worse than the former with the prices of the latter.  I was glad to find Tanuki in my neighborhood, and I would take anyone who likes sushi here--here's why.

If people like straight, traditional sushi, they won't be disappointed.  If they like American-syle rolls and novelties, they won't be disappointed either--the rolls are well made, with much better ingredients than you would normally get in a "fusion" style place; the uni shot was kind of incredible.  A good place to show California roll fans that real, simple sushi is different and can be better than something with 8 ingredients, two of them fried, topped with a mayonaise-based sauce.

The fish was fresh (especially the uni, which was obviously just-cleaned), the service was good, and everything was done right.  

They are Japanese and have Japanese customers--don't be fooled by the fact that you can get American-style sushi here.  They do that right too, and you can't fault them for being good businessmen.
author: Ben P.

description:
2.5 Stars

Came here on a Wednesday night after craving some oyster shooters. I heard about this place from a girl friend because it's so rare to find places that have oyster shooters. Also read the yelp reviews and wanted to give it a try. Got here at about 7pm and parking was a bit difficult. There was a slight wait, but got seated fairly quickly and hot tea was brought to our table shortly after.

We ordered the oyster shooters, the bamboo roll, the spicy hamachi roll, the scallop roll and I also wanted an uni shooter. After the waitress took our order, she came back and said they were out of uni.. bummer. But I was still excited for the oyster shooters! I normally don't like sake in mine so I asked for no sake.

Now this is why I'm deducting stars.. while everyone around us were seated after us, they kept getting our orders before us. But we were enjoying each others company so we compressed our tummies for a while longer anticipating our oyster shooters since that's the easiest order to make. Waited about 35 minutes before asking our waitress why it's taking so long while everyone else is getting their orders.. 5 minutes later she brings them out, but leaves before telling us which ones have sake and which ones don't. We wait for her to come back around to ask which ones are which and she looks puzzled and yells out at another waiter to see which ones are which. They all look at us as if we did something wrong and finally came back and told us that none of them have sake in them. Fine for me since that was what I originally wanted, but no apology of any kind to my friends who wanted sake in them. However, we let that slide.

Onto the next part.. we waited over an hour for our 3 rolls while everyone was still getting their food before ours! And the rolls weren't even hot! It's as if they were just sitting in the back, just chillin' there.

However, I enjoyed the oyster shooters and the scallop roll. Those two were my favorites, but I've had better. The spicy hamachi roll wasn't even spicy (and I don't have a high tolerance for spiciness) and the bamboo roll didn't have any kick to it.

Service definitely could've been better. All I hoped for was a simple apology that they messed up on our orders and having waited so long for everything to come out, but nope. Nothing.

I may be back.. Mainly because I can't get enough of oyster shooters!
author: Valerie T.

description:
Man, I don't know what has happened since the 1st time i've ventured into Tanuki. Service has definitely changed since Dec of '08. I guess it could also be an entirely different lineup of staff and an increase in business. 
3 out of 4 of the last times i've been to Tanuki started off very sour. Why? The service. Something about the servers here tells me that they don't know how to multi-task. Normally, i'd cut them a break and not be a bitch about shit but seriously this restaurant is not that big - it's very small. There's about 8 tables at most and 3 servers running around yet tonight it still somehow took TWENTY MINUTES to take my order?? 
After flagging down the servers, I had one waiter tell me "just a minute" 3x and the waitress told me "i'll be right back" twice. So in the timespan of twenty minutes, I was rejected FIVE TIMES. What went down those times? Other tables were cleared, food was taken out, and other tables' orders were taken. What the fuck man? Seriously?
My mom was remaining calm but I was ready to flip a table over and chop someone in the freaking babymaker. My mother tried to cut them some slack and said "maybe this isn't the waiter's section" I told her "seriously mom, how big is this restaurant?" So when the waitress rejected us, she started to crumble and snap.
So the twenty minutes went by and the male waiter finally took my order. Twenty minutes later, the first dish came out. So in total, it took 40 minutes until my family was able to take our first bites of food. My youngest brother was so hungry he fell asleep at the table. I shit you not. 
I can definitely say that this was not an isolated incident. 
There was another time when a friend and I had gone and it took 30 minutes for our food to come. We'd flag down the waiter and he'd just say "it's coming" and walk off. 

WOW.

Did you know that it's not really necessary to clear ONE MISO SOUP BOWL and walk it to the back? You can stop and take an order, swoop up the empty miso soup bowl and run the order afterwards? Seriously, you guys will cut down on walking back and forth a lot.. 
Tanuki, your sushi is good but not THAT good. I'm definitely not frequenting this place as often... I'll come when it's totally dead inside since your staff doesn't seem to know how to multi-task.
author: Susy C.

description: I've had dinner here in the past. The sushi & sashimi are always fresh! Never any disappointments here! Prices are reasonable. Service is always great! If you're looking for good, fresh sushi and sashimi, this is the place in the 'hood. Highly recommended!!
author: Annette L.

description:
3/5 not sure if this is a legit review..

we came here after chillin at dolores. you can imagine how we arrived.

we ordered a few rolls, nothing too out of the ordinary. my friend ranted and raved over the cold noodle salad that kinda tasted like potato salad. overall, can't say i remember much. not cuz it was bad, but because i tend to not remember what happened after dolores...
author: Alvin D.

description: Ate here a few nights ago - food nice but service slow & not attentive. Had to ask for napkins twice & no checking if we were ok or needed more drinks.
author: Madison S.

description:
I think this is the best deal in town for Japanese food during lunch in the Richmond district. 

Great Quality 
Great Price 
Clean 
Pure Japanese 

You would have never guessed that a caliber of this Restaurant can offer such a great deal during lunch. This will be one of my "go to" places for sushi during the weekdays. 

There's really isn't anything that sticks out. Just a very solid restaurant serving great food at very reasonable prices.
author: jason g.

description:
I love this place.

1. Close to home.
2. Freebies from the chef
3. Good quality items
4. Even though I come here after work sometime by myself, I always end up having a great conversation with a fellow patron at the sushi bar. 
5. I love the staff and chefs there!
author: Tiny H.

description: I ate at Tanuki for the first time in probably five years. It used to be five stars. This time, the sashimi was still excellent; everything else was kind of mediocre. The noodle salad starter was just kind of blah. The rice didn't seem up to standard. Maguro, though, was spot on. Still decent, but not as good as it used to be.
author: Joshua M.

description: I've only been on weeknights and it doesn't seem to fill up so I know that whenever i want sushi on a weeknight I can come by here. If you get a seat at the bar try ordering omakase - they really know what they are doing here. The fish was really fresh and the sushi chefs are friendly. The toro and the hotate were my favorite last time. My gf seems to really like their crab.  I haven't tried any of their rolls yet, but the ones on the specials board look interesting.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Happened upon this place while in the neighbourhood and looked thru Yelp.

They just opened for dinner and the place is almost empty. Looked cozy and the chefs are nice. However, we sat there for a while before the server came to take our order. They were really not busy, I swear!

Being a love of scallop, I have to say the harmony roll was very fresh and has pretty decent amount of protein.

The hot hamachi special was pretty disappointing. The sushi rolls are battered and fried that the hamachi was cooked thru instead of flash fried, then sat in a broth so it kind of defeated the deep frying.
author: Cindy B.

description: Prices shown online are not correct and restaurant will not honor online pricing.  They also have (2) different menus in at the restaurant that show different prices.  Definitely will not be going back to this place!!
author: Anne B.

description:
The food was pretty good, but the service was horrible.  After sitting for 15 minutes, I tried to grab someone to order, but they kept saying they would come back.  Finally 25 minutes after we sat down the waiter finally came over.  It seemed like they had only 2 people on the floor of the entire restaurant, and one of them told us she couldn't take orders.

When we finally got to eat (I was quite cranky at this point) the sushi rolls weren't anything out of the ordinary.  My favorite dish of the night was the deep fried crab and pumpkin tempura.  Big chunks of crab with sweet pumpkin.  Delicious!  

3 stars for food, minus 1 for service.
author: Nita K.

description:
I am a new neighbor of inner Richmond and I've been to Tanuki twice in the last few months. It is a fairly small place with no pretension. I wouldn't call it the best sushi I have ever had, however the quality is very decent. 
In my experience the service has always been pleasant and friendly, I find the fish fresh and the choice of sushi varied. 

Tanuki might not be coming to mind for fancy dinner but it is definitely a place where I'll get my quick fix of sushi!
author: Cemeldosce M.

description:
This is a pretty good japanese restaurant. its VERY VERY small so its not really good for big groups. the staff is very welcoming and always come around and ask if you need anything. the best part is their noodle salad. its SOO good and different from any regular noodle salad! it comes with the meals so you dont need to worry about ordering it. I got the chicken terriyaki and it was a prety large portion and also very good. 

I would definitely recommend this place and come back!
author: Stephanie W.

description:
Let's start with the fact that I REALLY wanted to love this place. 

The bf and I just moved to Inner Richmond and we are on a serious hunt for delicious sushi at a fantastic sushi place. Well, this place was a definitely BUST.

BF, myself and a friend went in on a Tuesday night at around 7pmish. The place is relatively small and it was pretty slow.  We were sat and given green tea.  So good so far.... Well, then it took the server TWENTY MINUTES to come over to us and see what we wanted to drink and take our order. The sushi was good, nothing to write home about. But it's the service that seriously killed this place.  There were 2 servers and they both essentially ignored us.   Even when we ordered, never asked how it was or if we needed a refill of sake. I had to call the waiter over to tell us what fish was on our sashimi platter. 

The service was HORRIBLE. The sushi was ok.

NEVER COMING BACK!
author: Amy Y.

description:
AFter reading several reviews here on Yelp, my sister and two friends and I decided to try out Tanuki. As some reviews have already mentioned, the service is fairly slow, however the sushi itself is fantastic. We got several different rolls and a couple orders of nigiri. Nothing short of perfection. 

Aside from somewhat slow service, it will not stop me from recommending and returning to Tanuki.
author: Lauren K.

description:
With a sushi restaurant on every block in the city, it's easy to get overwhelmed by the quantity of possible selections. How do you sort out the gems from the riffraff? That's easy: ask an expert. I am lucky enough to have a friend who knows San Francisco dining exceptionally well and forunate enough to have received Tanuki as the ultimate sushi recommendation.

I visited Tanuki on a Tuesday, stayed for several orders of sushi and was thrilled to see how popular this place is. Hit or miss parking and a general distance from the busiest part of the neighborhood, yet a full dining room? Excellent sign. A traditional menu and quick, friendly service? Check. Constant laughter and smiles from both the chefs preparing and the servers delivering our food? I'm sold. 

Menu must haves: Ankimo, the Tanuki roll, outstanding yellowtail and maguro sashimi. If you love oysters in the excessive, unhealthy way that my dinner date and I do, order a dozen. You won't be sorry. 

Five stars all around, Tanuki is the gold standard for Bay Area sushi.
author: Jules H.

description:
Tanuki on California St.  Place is nice and clean. My only thing was it's a little space. There's front window seating which is along the sushi bar and then off to the side is a little more seating. That's as much as I saw. 

As for the food...  It was so yummy!  We had Hamachi and Salmon Sashimi, and there was the monk liver fish, akimono?  A few sushi rolls, Hamachi Collar, all good foods...  I had a great time, and when you get there and if you're lucky enough, you may get one of the several front door spaces...  VERY CONVENIENT if you have little kids....

Can't wait to go back again...
author: Cheryl N.

description: I have been coming here for years! However, it is usually for a special occasion because the prices are a bit high. The service is great! They got my order wrong here one time and they happily replaced it with my correct order without charging anything. Everything on the menu is good, and I love their noodle salad that they give with their entrees! The udon is superb here! Definitely worth a try!
author: Lauren D.

description: Humility is a hard thing to find in the dining world, especially in a town that's impressed with chutneys, reductions, and Bobby Flay.  Tanuki is a refreshing change of pace because the focus is on what's in front of you, not the dazzle of trends and blog buzz.  Featuring light tempura, a courteous staff, and the softest, sweetest white tuna sashimi that has ever grace my palate, Tanuki must be the Japanese equivalent of comfort food because all that earnestness shines through.
author: Michael D.

description:
I very rarely venture to the city for dinner with friends -- let alone the Richmond District -- but Tanuki was HIGHLY recommended, so this is where we landed.

Great choice for the area!

---FOOD/BOOZE---
Of the things I tried:

1) Sashimi Combination, $20+
- Super fresh, thick slices of sashimi. The 14-piece combo plate with a huge variety ranging from tuna to salmon to mackerel to octapus to even sea urchin all served on top of fresh grated daikon. Delicious!

2) Rainbow Roll, $15
- Very very fresh and with a very unique combination of fish on top of the roll. (No avocado, but octapus!). Definitely on the pricier end though -- $15!

3) Hamachi Roll (Special on menu), $12ish
- Also very fresh, and a bit on the spicy side. 

4) Side: Fried Mackerel, $?
- Fried  lightly to perfection! 

5) Side: Beef tounge, $?
- Wow...never had it Japanese style (only lengua tacos)...super tender, charred so the edges are slightly crisped, and very savory. With a squeeze of lemon..simply delicate. 

5) Karatanba Sake, $13ish/bottle
- My goodness...I never thought I would ever come across sake that tasted as good as unfiltered nigori...but this is absolutely smooth and fresh! I will DEFINITELY be on the look out for this at other Japanese restaurants!

6) Saporo, $6ish/large bottle
- They don't serve Kirin here...

---PRICES---
As you can see from the above prices, it is fairly steep. I would consider giving this place 5-stars...if I hadn't JUST had Yojimbo last week in Alameda. (Charashi Bowl with 15-slices of really fresh sashimi...for only $9.75! Yea...you can't beat that!). 

---AMBIANCE---
Very small, homey feel with authentic (not overly done) Japanese decor. What I liked most about this place is that it was Saturday night, quite a gem, and NOT uberly packed. We didn't have to wait at all for seats! 

---SERVICE---
I believe the sushi chef's name is "Aki" (..Sake for Aki!?..lol) and his son was his sous sushi chef. Very friendly, welcoming, attentive, and smiley. So friendly they'd take sake shots with us! Haha. Reminds me of my favorite sushi place in Vegas -- Sushimon (uninhibited drinking = high quality sashimi and good times!).

---PARKING---
It's SF. On a Saturday. VERY LIMITED.

---FINALLY---
I would definitely come back if I were in this area again! 

But, luckily...I don't have to pay toll and stress over parking whenever I crave great sashimi (at a great price!). Just gotta head over to Alameda =).
author: Gail N.

description:
Hmmmm....

I didn't have a bad experience at all, I just didn't think it was all that great. My friend told me this was one of the best sushi places in the area. Its the only sushi place I've been to in the area but, its not that amazing.

First off- I expected it to be packed. It was Saturday around 8 and it was my group and a couple in the restaurant. My initial thought was, maybe this place isn't all that after all.

I ordered the grilled chicken teriyaki and the house special roll. The chicken teriyaki was pretty good, but there wasn't much of it. It was $16 and I could've made that myself for less than $16. It was too much for what they gave. 

I asked the waiter what their most popular roll was and he said the house special. It was huge, but I had better. 

If I were craving expensive sushi I would go here. If i wanted quality sushi I would go somewhere else. This place is good, dont' get my wrong, but Its not that great for the price.
author: Anthony V.

description:
I love this place. I got sick just the other day and did NOT have an appetite at all. My friend asked if there was anything I needed, I thought that eating would be forcing something not meant to be. But when I scanned all the places in my neighborhood, Tanuki was my saving grace. 
Now I feel a hell of a lot better, thanks to Tanuki. 

Also, I LOVE their UDON. They have big thick noodles that come in an iron pot. Wait, I'll say it again: They have big thick noodles... 
Their chefs really know how to cut fish. I've never had to pull out things out of my mouth when chomping on nigiri.
author: Danielly A.

description:
Tanuki means Raccoon in Japanese, and is the name of a famous Samurai in Japan who was known as a crafty and deceptive warrior.  The sushi at Tanuki however is not Raccoon nor shifty, it is fresh and traditional.

Having lived in Tokyo for a year I love finding authentic Japanese restaurants in San Francisco.  I've only been twice to Tanuki but each time it has been easy to get a seat, service has been slow but fine, and the fish super fresh and all the other dishes delicious.  Definitely a top 5 must dine Japanese restaurant in SF.
author: Dave L.

description:
Been to Tanuki on California a handful of times and it never disappoints. It's a small, neighborhood spot, but the quality of the nigiri and sashimi is on par with any of Morimoto's pricey uptown joints. 

Staff is always friendly in the standard, almost overly polite way that you only experience in an authentic Japanese family restaurant. 

Everything was fresh and tasty. The uni was delicious. Hey, I realize that 'the custard of the sea' is an acquired taste, but don't be a pansy. If you're a texture person, brace yourself for a gob of fish flavored avocado.

The 16oz Asahi draft for $5.50 is an outstanding value.

Oh, one last thing... The master sushi chef looks like he might know Mr. Miyagi... and although it may appear that he isn't paying attention... the sly old fox hears everything. Don't get silly and end up with your extremeties tempura'd.
author: Kevin A.

description:
If you're in a mixed group of tastes, this is a perfect place to come for sushi. They have *excellent* sashimi for the connoisseurs and refined palettes, and very good rolls for those, well...without. I am in the second category myself--I have no shame. I love gringo-rolls (as I call them) with cream cheese, veggies, baked salmon... all that rich stuff. Tanuki caters to both parties equally. They also have GREAT looking udon... I wish I had ordered some myself. Perhaps next time.

They split our bill between 5 credit cards... not ideal... but the fact that they did it without giving us grief is note-worthy.

Also, they have a TV on with sports, if that is a deal breaker one way or the other for you...
author: Rachel L.

description: This is definitely a neighborhood gem.  This is traditional Japanese food at its best in quality and pricing.  The sashimi and sushi are amazing as are their daily specials.  Their combinations are very reasonably priced and of great quality.  Definitely try their noodle salad.  We usually have lunch at least once a week at Tanuki.  The service is very attentive with Yuki managing the dining room.   This is  a place where their are a lot of regulars that come to dine.  They have just re-open after retro-fitting their bathroom.  Great job and keep up the good work.
author: Frank L.

description:
I've been coming here for years. When I mean years, I mean like close to 20 years and I'm 25. My mom used to work on 6th Ave at Bank of Orient back in the 80s. She introduced us to this place and we've been going since for dinner a few times a month. I'm not a sushi person, but my mom and brother order the raw fish stuff. They seem to enjoy it. 

Sometimes I'll order the Tonkatsu w/ Tempura or Beef or Chicken. I'd recommend the chicken fried. I've yet to have a bad meal here. Service is good. It can get busy Friday nights since the place is not very big so I'd recommend to come early and also to find parking.
author: Jerold C.

description:
A very nice semi hidden gem in the inner richmond. Small but not cramped place for a nice dinner among friends.  

Let me start off by stating that this is a japanese owned establishment so I quickly look for certain entrees like futomaki which is the original roll usually consisting of japanese cucumber, egg, carrot, fish cake and kampyo. This one had crab too. Very nice! We also had negi hama as well. Equally good too.

I had the uni (sea urchin) and ikura with azura (salmon roe and raw quail egg) because it's my fav. Not bad. The saba (mackeral) was excellent.

Hot dishes were the oyako don, tempura tenzaru soba and tempura udon. High praise for the udon texture and the all important broth...just right (not too salty or watery). The tempura batter was good too (not too thick and heavy). The oyaku don could've had more of a sweet flavor to it, but a very nice dish to have. A big plus was the chawan mushi (egg custard flavored with shitake mushrooms, shrimp and other cool ingredients). Excellent !

All in all, very good sushi/entrees with nice presentation as well as friendly japanese-english speaking wait service. The prices were very reasonable too with the portion size that you get as well! The only thing missing was the traditional vinegar rice flavor in the sushi rice which is something you don't see often anymore but is an expectation in a japanese owned sushi restaurant. Will be back again for more!
author: Moses G.

description:
Came for: group dinner for sushi sushi sushi
Will come back for: great sushi / sashimi / other japanese fares

Could it be?  I wasn't sure what to expect on my first visit as the choice for the group outing was based on yelpers...  well, you all did not disappoint; it was.  
It was good!  We had quite a spread and chowed down through them: nabeyaki udon, various rolls, daily specials (crab & pumpkin roll), and sashimi. 

Personal favorites:
yellow tail sashimi - fresh, generous-sized pieces that melted in my mouth
bamboo roll - this albacore tuna wrapped in rice topped with hamachi and avocado was also generous portions with fresh fish pieces
oyster shooter - not many sushi places have these, so I get excited to find and have them (they also had uni shooters that day)

Our group enjoyed as did I; it was a solid experience.  Moreover, the moderate price points make it a good choice for group outings, quick go-to's and when you simply want some good sushi without having to break your piggy bank.
This could be a contender for my other go-to sushi place in SF.  Will just have to go back to confirm.
author: Carol K.

description:
Pro: Sushi was fine, had the tropical roll, negi-hama roll and tuna nigiri.  Tasted all right, tropical was good.  Nothing that would rock your world though.

Con:  What did rock our world was the sickness we both got about 30 minutes after eating.  I've never been more unhappy to have a 1 bedroom, 1 bathroom apartment after that night.  

I dare say we will not be returning, better sushi can be had in the Richmond that does not make you sick.
author: Ben E.

description:
"Ama-ebi, ama-ebi, amma, amma, ama-ebi"
sing to the tune of Imma Be by the Black Eyed Peas.

Amaebi on the next level - seriously. So good, I can't write this without craving it. The raw shrimp is amazingly sweet, typically I think raw shrimp as Ebi and it's always been kind of blah, amaebi is ebi to the 10th power in tastiness. I sucked the tail just to get every last piece out. At Tanuki's they also serve the heads to you and they give you the option to have it either fried or in a broth. I of course had it fried and ate every edible part of the thing, eyes and all. Great great great. After trying amaebi here its become a staple of every Japanese dinner I go to.

Here are other things to order:
- Charashi - about 12 pieces of fish, tamago (egg), and mushrooms. The mushrooms were a great addition, they were so sweet - not sure if they were seasoned that way or just naturally taste like that, but either way good. All the fish was incredibly fresh and each piece melted on our tongues.
- Uni - freshness in mush, disintegrates in your mouth. Advice from BF, eat with uni facing tongue for ultimate taste experience.
author: Nicole L.

description:
My latest personal economic indicator is just in: for a special occasion, I was going to take my mate to 5th Floor, but like the rest of America, I decided to be conservative. We went back to Tanuki instead.

We were disappointed. We ran out of tea, and were not offered any more. This has not happened in three years. They ran out of toro. Then, when we ordered hamachi toro, it was clear they were running out of that. The ankimo we ordered was completely the wrong texture, and lacked flavor. 

The toro we did consume was terrific. The hamachi toro, though slightly strangely cut, was also very good. 

Finally, and this is not really Tanuki's fault, but it is totally annoying: why can't servers learn to put the check in the middle of the table instead of in front of the dude? It is sooo awkward when the dude is not paying to have to have him hand you a check..

I'm hoping they just had a bad night, because I really can't live without toro.
author: H G.

description:
sushi was good. definitely NOT the best, i ever had, and they are way overpriced

pretty disappointed. 

*(disclaimer: i only ordered raw fish, as i do at every sushi restaurant. i have not tried any lunch specials..)
author: Lisa N.

description: Great place, outstanding sushi, friendly service. One of my favorite places. Definetely, will be back and back and back! Just had a dinner - delicious.
author: James D.

description: Delicious Japanese food! A mellow, friendly little place. Had a great bento box of teriyaki, tempura and sashimi (with rice, seaweed and mackerel) for $12.50. And - it's baby friendly! Our server immediately brought out a booster seat, plus a little plastic bowl, mini-utensils and a mini-cup of water with a straw, plus a cookie for desert. We really appreciated the gesture, as it's tough to eat out with a baby. Fast and friendly service, fresh and nicely presented food.
author: Jen Z.

description:
You have not lived until you've eaten the "Crab Avacado Roll". It has crab inside, and avacado, salmon, and lemon piled on top. YUM! My boyfriend and I visit this restaurant on a bi-weekly basis and we order that roll Every Time. 

I'm a big fan of this particular sushi restaurant for several reasons. It's a cute little restaurant and all the staff are very nice. The fish is very good, and I recommend asking the waiter/ress which fish is freshest because it varies a little - though the Hamachi Toro is usually on the list.. and it makes fantastic shashimi. The only thing I think I had here which I didn't like was perhaps the Spanish Mackrel, but I don't know if it was just that time, or if that's a fish they don't stock as regularly.

I do have to make the confession that I haven't tried much other than sushi here - just the tempera and edamame, which were good as well. I've been there once with a friend who ordered a dinner off the menu, and she liked it a lot, but I can't say that from first-hand experience. I'm too addicted to the sushi to give it a try as of yet.. ;)
author: Kristine K.

description: I was really hoping to find a new good sushi place in this city, but was disappointed yet again. Fishy sushi and the tataki was overcooked. Gomae lacked flavor. The fatty tuna roll was good. But the decor was just really sad and the place had a weird smell. It made me lose my appetite. In sum, not the worst, but not the worth the trip to the Richmond.
author: Blond E.

description: Excellent tempura; teriyaki beef, salmon, and chicken; soup and salads. My friend asked for extra teriyaki sauce which was a great idea. We didn't try any sushi or sashimi, but everything we had was very fresh and flavorful.
author: Leo T.

description:
Food = meh,

Service = HORRIBLE 

Desperately wanted this to be my neighborhood sushi favorite.  However, the service is effing TERRIBLE -- we were basically ignored for 20 minutes, told that the waiter was the only one who could take our order. (YES - they only have ONE waiter!). We could barely order extra drinks, let alone get water.  Our "quick" neighborhood sushi meal transformed into an hour and a half. The food was OK but totally not worth the hassle of the service. While my order was alright, my boyfriend's roll was not good at all. I will not go back here.
author: Gillian M.

description:
First time I came here was well over twenty years ago with my very first girlfriend.  Back then, it was a very reasonably priced, authentic Japanese restaurant that was okay, but nothing to write home about.  I quickly forgot about it. 

Fast forward to the present day...I was able to jump a miraculous hurdle in the repair of one of my Corvettes and after some other good news, decided to go out to dinner.  Was going to go to Chou Chou, but had seen Tanuki on Yelp recently and decided to go there instead

It took some time after sitting down, but we finally got our menus.  Wow, what a difference the years make.  Was surprised at the high prices on the menu, but figured they went upscale and looked forward to some good food.  I ordered two large sakes, hamachi kama appetizer (grilled yellowtail collar...one of my Japanese faves), and a bunch of sushi.  My friend ordered Tempura with Prawns and as she ordered, asked the young waiter what kind of vegetables were in the tempura.

They were out of the large hamachi kama, so we got a small.  It was good, but not great.  Super salty in some spots and then no salt in others.  Personally, I like salty as that's authentic, but this one didn't impress.

I was impressed with the freshness of the sushi there, especially the fresh salmon nigiri.  However, I was not impressed with the sake (smoked salmon) nigiri at all.  Not only was it multi-colored from reddish at the edges to an odd dull pale color in the center, it looked old and freezer burned.

The unakyu roll was excellent.  If only it had been just a touch smaller, it would have been perfect.  I admit that I often prefer value over authentic size, but in this case, it was an outside-in roll with rice on the outside.  As such, it was too big to eat in one bite, yet a messy pain to eat in two bites because of the nori on the inside of the rice.  Regardless, it was delicious.

It suddenly dawned on us that there were no prawns in her tempura.  We brought it to the attention of our waiter, a young guy who looked like he was waiting tables while in college.  He told us that no, Vegetable Tempura is what she ordered.  This obviously wasn't the case as there is no way in h#ll she would have ordered just vegetables, but we politely explained that she had ordered it with prawns so he went back to talk to the cook.

About eight minutes later, he came out and told us that he could bring us an order of prawns, but would have to charge us for the separate order.  I nicely explained to him with a smile that she had not ordered Vegetable Tempura, but rather Tempura with Prawns (which includes vegetable).  My thought is why should we be penalized for HIS mistake?

After that, he went back again.  This time, it felt like he was gone like fifteen minutes before he finally came back.  By then, I was pretty much through with my own meal yet we were still trying to get hers straightened out.  When he came back, he did not have an answer, but instead asked rather bluntly, "So, what did you want to do?"  I almost lost it and wanted to say, "What do I want to do?...Hell, shouldn't that be what do YOU want to do?"  Instead, I pulled out my rudimentary Japanese and told him that I can't understand what the problem is when she ordered Tempura with Prawns in the first place.  After that, he thought about it and then said Tempura with Prawns is $2.00 more than Vegetable Tempura.  I told him that's no problem since first of all, its only $2.00 and its what she ordered in the first place.  Grrrrrrrrrrrrr.

Fifteen to twenty minutes later (I'm not kidding, it seemed even longer), they finally brought out a small plate with two small, but perfectly fried prawns.  Not sure if that order usually comes with only two prawns (hard to imagine!), but at this point we were so tired of the whole ordeal that we didn't have the energy to say anything.

Obviously, there was a language issue, but I still feel like he was originally going to charge us not $2.00, but rather for a whole new order of tempura prawns to cover his mistake.  Also, I have to question the intelligence of the way the whole thing was handled.  A seasoned professional waiter would have instantly acknowledged that for whatever reason, the order had been miscommunicated and corrected it immediately.  The menu price difference should not even have been brought up as an issue nor should we have been told that they would have to charge us.  All they had to do was reflect the proper price of what we originally ordered on the final bill.  Regardless, I was generous and still tipped well.  Wondering why this morning.

I was not impressed with the experience and felt that the place was also overpriced for a former family style restaurant with new upscale aspirations.  Way too many good Japanese restaurants in SF to suffer through this again.  At those prices, we should have just gone to Chou Chou for reasonable French like I originally intended.  Oh well.
author: Roy N.

description:
It was Monday night.
Most of Sushi place closed on Monday.
But Tanuki is open for 7 days.

This place is 100% Japanese.

There was a sushi chef only be here when owner needs a break.
He was my kind.
"Shari " was begger.
Not too sweet.
good long slice of "Neta" over with dimple.
And I like the way he holds Nigiri.
He was in to it. 120%.
Oh Man,
He looked like he was having some kind of ecstasy.
Seriously!
You can tell by watching him making Nigiri.

I usually don't like to talk with sushi chef.
But this chef asked me where I from, so we started a little chit chat.
So I found out that this guy is just a substitute for the night.
So,
I had to go back there again to see the owner chef.
It was a busy night but owner chef was also good.
But , to me, I like the substitute better.

I should go back there on Monday.
I like to tell you that their waitresses were very good.
And the price was resonable.
Just right.
My kind of place.
author: Nobu K.

description:
I'm completely at a loss on this one... after reading everyone else's reviews, I swear I must've gone to a different restaurant - but I checked and double and triple checked! My main man at sushi, Nobu, loves this place - what parallel universe with Spock's evil twin did I stumble into?

My girlfriend and I had wanted to try Tanuki for a while and were giddy that we could this saturday night. What a huge disappointment. We sat at the sushi bar and it smelled fishy. WTF? I tried hard not to notice that the fish was stacked haphazardly in the cooler and that the salmon looked improperly trimmed with lots of brown on it - indicating a cut too close to the skin. And then there was the rice...

I had always hoped of one day being capable of discerning different qualities of rice. No problemo here! The vinegar was wrong - as in there was none because it all tasted like clumpy, sticky white rice. And that's all you'd taste because there were gobs and gobs of it messing up the fish. The rice messed up the bland rolls as they disintegrated at my chopsticks light touch. The nigiri was hopeless. They were the weirdest thing I'd ever seen - big floppy blankets of fish plopped on top of more of that damned white rice. 

We couldn't bring ourselves to finish the fish or rolls. None of the "spicy" rolls were spicy and the Fire roll was disgusting. The hamachi was gristly and smelled bad.

I feel terrible writing this review because everyone was really nice there. I'm just calling it as I saw it. Unfortunately, truth be told, my girlfriend lost her cookies when we got home. Ug.
author: Brady K.

description: Every sushi chef in town should come here to re-charge their batteries - it's the real deal!  I almost hate to tell anyone about this neighborhood gem.  For a long time it's been our little secret.  But guilt is a powerful thing...
author: Dave C.

description: Every dish I had here so far has been superb. Amazing I even ate things I normally dislike as in the california roll and the sashimi and it was way phuckin' good!!!!
author: Adamma I.

description:
What a shame that the service has to bring down an otherwise great restaurant.  I realize that servers get busy and it's not always easy to be at everyone's beck and call, but it took forever them to 1. take our order2. get our soup/salads and 3. get the check right (more on that later).

The miso soup was good but certainly not the best I've had.  The saba shioyaki was delicious and tender but the portion was a bit smaller than what I'm used to.  For $9.50 they better put a huge hunk of mackerel on my plate.  Who the hell loves mackerel besides me and a few select others anyway?  Yeah, exactly.  :)

And of course when I needed water, my server was nowhere to be found.  Sure, she didn't know that I was going through coke withdrawal from having given it up but it doesn't hurt to check in every now and then, right?

So the check comes and next to "saba" I see "$12.  Uhhh, no.  When I looked at the menu it was $9.50.  I wasn't gonna make a big deal if it was a few cents but fuck, almost $3?  I voiced my opinion to the server who tried telling me I was wrong.  Surely enough, I was right and she changed it.  

To say I was annoyed is an understatement.  I honestly couldn't wait to just pay her and be done with them.  There are plenty of good sushi places that not only carry high quality fish but also don't try to SCREW YOU in the process.  I am listening to Nancy Reagan on this one.  JUST SAY NO.
author: Emily C.

description:
I have threewords for this place... Toro, Hamachi, and monk fish liver (I forget the name in Japanese). DELICIOUS!!! The taste of all those three just melt in your mouth! They are really fresh and yummy. I have no other way to describe them! You just have to try them yourself. 

The owner are a Japanese couple. They are very nice people. We went there for dinner, but before we started to eat our first order, we had to move to the bar area because people came in with a big party. So, we moved. Everybody couldn't stop saying thank you to us, and we got a free food as a trade! and an awesome one that have became my favorite. WOW!!

Prices?! They are surprisingly decent! Can't really find that kind of sushi or sashimi with decent prices in San Francisco!
author: Daisy S.

description:
Oh Tanuki.....you're not a one hit wonder, and every time I come back I realize how I've missed you so.  Since I live on the peninsula I don't get up here as often as I like, which might make it all the more magical for me each time.

I've been here a smidgen over a handful of times and everything is always just as I imagine it. Their fish is super fresh, sashimi is perfectly cut and the presentation is simple yet elegant.  Agedashi is so, so, so good. It's a bowl of delicious lightly fried tofu with the plethora of scallions, seaweed and dashi broth.  Service has always been great, even when they are packed to the gills with people waiting anxiously at the door they are always friendly, attentive, and efficient.  We've never waited long for our food too which is a surprise considering how crowded it can get.  

If you go you have to try their crab & pumpkin tempura, what a perfect combo. Oh, and their loose leaf genmaicha is heavenly.

I just finished stuffing myself to the point of discomfort a couple of hours ago and I almost feel as if I could do another Tanuki round...
author: Kristine T.

description:
As far as I can tell, it's good form to buy the chef a drink when you're sitting at the sushi bar.  But I don't really think it's such good form to get him so wasted he can't do his job.  Some drunk knuckleheads kept giving our chef shots of sake and the guy was three sheets while making our food.  Not that he was complaining.  I have a feeling this wasn't his first time making sushi under the influence.  And I got the impression he might have been the owner so it didn't seem like he had to answer to anyone.

Anyway, I wouldn't really care about a drunk sushi chef if the food was good, but it wasn't.  My friend and I kept giving each other that "what a bummer this place isn't better because I really was in the mood for sushi" look as we ate.
author: George C.

description:
Super-fresh.
A-typical menu offering is a nice change.  Oh how tired we get of seeing "49'er Roll" at some places!  Several sake choices to compliment your order.

The service is always friendly, and there's always a good crowd inside.
author: Ken B.

description:
I can't always make it to Cha-Ya or Minako for true veggie Japanese food, but Tanuki has more than enough options to satisfy any vegetarian/vegan's palate.  And to make a more balanced review, the actual sushi also got a thumbs up from my meat-eating counterpart.

Otherwise, the friendly and knowledgeable waitstaff serve you in that typical Japanese restaurant setting where seats are closely spaced, but minus the annoyingly loud techno music that proliferates in trendier joints.  It's not surprising a restaurant like Taunki resides here; it fits in, surrounded amongst other great restaurants along the California/Clement St. corridor in the Inner Rich.
author: Marsha Z.

description: It is awesome, sit at the bar and just enjoy dish after dish... Aki is the chef have a shot with him :)
author: Philippe R.

description:
I really dont have much to say about the food...except for delicious.

service was very good and I will definitely come back here again.

Very warming atmosphere, waitresses and chefs are all very polite.
author: phillip w.

description: Great traditional Japanese food. Consistently good quality.  Family - owned restaurant. Service excellent. We have been going there for 20 years.
author: arnold s.

description:
Our chef friend took us here for some really good sushi.  I tried a lot of things for the first time; uni, amaebi, scallop, monkfish liver, hamachi collar.
