Then I had other things that were much better than I've had, mirugai for example.  Everything was excellent, we especially liked the uni, hamachi collar and amaebi, which comes with a HUGE piece of fried shrimp head.  Sushi rice is seasoned properly and all the staff is Japanese.

The only downside is the place is quite small and the server can get a bit flustered when busy.  All is forgotten though once the food arrives.
author: Derrick V.

description:
this review is for sushi only as I didn't order anything else.

Walking by this neighborhood on a sat night, it was dark, cold and quiet. This restaurant was completely full, so I gotta give it a try.

Crab avocado roll (ca roll topped w/ lemon wedges/salmon/avodaco) 
- very fresh and delicous $12 was a bit overpriced tho.

The rest were very fresh as well but not the Tamago, it was not made fresh but store bought $3.5 was also overpriced I think.

Overall they deliver fresh good sushi rolls and excellent service. However, for the same quality, there are many sushi places that is about 20% less expensive.
author: Maggie C.

description:
Received a recommendation from a friend to try Tanuki so we headed here this week. Delicious!

The service was very polite , very efficient. We sat at the sushi bar and ordered several rolls. Each one met or exceeded our expectations. The Negi-Toro was delicious and I was pleasantly surprised by their spicy scallops - not drowning in a spicy mayo sauce like you find so many places these days. The Foil steamed crab, salmon and mushrooms was delicious as was the Fried White Onion Garlic roll. One of my personal favorites, the ume-shiso roll, was the best I've had in years.

We will be back - this is quite possibly our new favorite sushi spot!
author: Tara D.

description:
Been eating here since time immemorial and their food has not changed in taste but only gotten better.  We live across the bay but when we're in San Francisco we go to the same Japanese restaurant that will give you the best taste in Japanese cooking.  Somehow, I didn't feel like saying something good about this restaurant just so there would be no long line or long wait before they could seat you.  But, even after waiting long, you'll get satisfied after eating here.

I was single then when my dad introduced me to this restaurant who is hooked on to this restaurant, first. Now,  I'm married I got my husband hooked on to this place.  He's favorite is their Chicken Teriyaki, used to liked their Nabeyaki Udon but when he tried their chicken teriyaki, he would not stop ordering the same.  I have ordered their Salmon Teriyaki - medium well and it's the best!  The cold noodle salad that comes with it is just perfect.
author: Loretta M.

description:
Really good spot for good sushi and super fresh sashimi! 

The sashimi combo specifically was right on! 

I highly recommend this place for the price, food and service. Parking is a challenge here but what neighborhood is not in SF?
author: Al G.

description:
I went here yesterday for lunch w/ a couple of buddies after a really busy day of runnin' around for his wedding stuff.  Everyone was starving, and reminiscing of the hella good sushi lunch buffet from Fuji's in Davis, the decision was made to have get some sushi.  It was nice that this place takes reservations for large groups too, b/c we had 10 people hungry and expecting good sushi.

This restaurant came through w/ some damn good sushi and fried teriyaki chicken (never had fried chicken before at a Japanese restaurant, but it was good, so no complaints).  Oh yea, like someone else mentioned in their review, it was a pleasant surprise to see a sushi restaurant w/ actual Japanese people working there (perhaps just seems to make a bit more authentic experience I suppose).

We ordered some fried calamari for starters, then had HELLA sushi rolls (rainbow rolls, spider rolls, dragon rolls, avocado rolls, etc.)  I got so freakin' stuffed from the food, I couldn't even finish all that we ordered.  Needless to say, I was pretty happy w/ the food I got here.  Any restaurant that gives quantity w/o sacrificing quality, always going to get thumbs up from me.
author: Minh V.

description:
So glad I discovered this place tonight! Great quality fish and the specials were very tasty. 

Sashimi Combo - fresh. 
House Roll - it was okay. even though it had a lot of good stuff in it, I didn't think it stood out all that much. 
Space Roll - pretty simple.
"Foil" (special) - this is a very tasty hot dish! foil wrapped crab, salmon,and mushrooms served with ponzu sauce. highly recommend. 
Nasu-don - I love eggplant so I had to order this. it was good but not the best i've had. 
clam miso soup - i love the clam miso at Tekka so I wanted to try this out. Overall pretty good but the miso soup itself was not as light as I wanted it to be. 

Overall, I had a great experience here and would definitely come back.
author: Q C.

description:
This is a 3.5 star review - the wimpy sushi rolls we got here were very good BUT the biggest turn off EVER in a restaurant is the awful STANK of fish. This place smelled like bad sushi - and I was scared at first.

The Heavenly roll was HEAVENLY - fantastic tuna. The Harmony roll was the perfect harmony of spicy and scallop. And the Tokyo roll was good even though it included salmon - yay score one for you Tanuki. 

Oddly, Ali Gato R. and I felt the sushi rice here was strangely good...just something to note.

This place was good, fast, but SMELLY. Go to Chin's across the street for a less smelly experience, cheaper dishes and wider selection.
author: Jessica L.

description:
I love this place.  I really, really do.  Got the chawan mushi again (it's GOOD and unlike most places, you don't have to call ahead and special order it)!  Also ordered the lobster hand roll and various nigiri, including white tuna, hamachi and amaebi.  

It's not the fanciest place ever, but they always make you feel at home and Aki-san always gives us a ton of delicious extra goodies.  Tonight he busted out some hot soup with amaebi heads, a bowl of little sausages, and ahi with okra.  SO TASTY.  Tummy happy.
author: Riya K.

description:
This is easily one of my favorite places in the area and one of the most common names that I recommend when asked for good Japanese restaurants. The prices are consisent and expected for sushi, so people shouldn't leave feeling like they got ripped off.  I recommend the hamachi sashimi, Tanuki roll, hamachi kama, ume & shiso roll (i'm not a fan of ume, but somehow i like it here), and steamed clams in broth (absolutely satisfying on a cold night).

The vibe is more homey and family-oriented than it is a date spot for music and decor. Parking within a block radius is possible if you prefer early dinners (I usually dine here before 7pm). Otherwise, you may have to spend about 5 minutes circling around Clement or California Streets (overall, parking isn't a big hindrance).
author: Valerie F.

description:
I have been coming to this place since 1992...one of the sushi chefs was still a server! I've brought all my friends and family over, and everyone wants to keep coming back over and over...and we have.

My favorites: the can't-miss oyster shooters (great with sake), the best teriyaki chicken in SF (my guess is they marinade this in tons of garlic overnight, douse it with flour and deep-fry---yummy!), and just consistently high quality sushi.
author: Michelle Y.

description:
I was impressed with San Francisco's health rating post of 100 for this restaurant.  The restaurant is clean and the food here is good.  For starters, the dinner comes with miso soup (comes with big chunks of tofu and seafood), rice, and cold noodle salad (a little too much mayonnaise).  My order was the combination sashimi and grilled teriyaki chicken.  The sashimi was excellent.  I didn't care much for the grilled chicken as it was a fairly thin piece of chicken which didn't have much kick in flavor.  Other members in my party ordered the fried teriyaki chicken, fried seafood, and tempura.  These items were fried to perfection; nice fried browned coloring and batter texture.  Heard the taste was very good.  There is a sushi bar in this restaurant.

Tanuki's is fairly small.  At most, a party of eight would be okay.
author: Nanette L.

description: The tropical roll (mango & 2 types of tuna) is divine!  Check out the chalkboard for the day's chef's specials.  Fantastic service as well.  We'll be back for sure!
author: Dave C.

description: I came here with some friends and absolutely loved it! Everything is very fresh and the fish quality is high. I loved the oyster shots and the sashimi combo. Unfortunately, I'm a student and can't afford to eat here too much, but I'm definitely looking forward to coming here again!
author: Jenn C.

description: Update.  Consistently fresh and delicious.  Traditional sushi is the core offering and Aki-san delivers every time.  He is also extremely friendly to boot.  Treat yourself to authentic sushi without pretense. The interior has a nice neighborly feel with a prominent bar as well as table seating.  My favorite sushi restaurant in SF.
author: A D.

description:
I love going to eat with my old, city-girl auntie for several reasons....1.) She always treats, 2.) She always knows the good places in the city, 3.) She always knows some gossip about the owners or the place itself and the place's history. So, over her cold soba noodles with tempura and my gomae and california roll, I hear about the place used to be half it's size when they first opened up. There used to be a cleaners next door and they bought the place and extended the restaurant out to it's present size. The sushi chef and his wife run the place and she has heard the wife likes to go betting on the horse races. The house on the corner had a fire and was gutted for several years so that side of the street looked kind of crummy but is now rebuilt. We see another elderly Japanese woman walking down the street outside the restaurant and she tells me that the lady is 96 years old and walks 6 blocks to shop on Clement Street every day. 
Oh, and the food was pretty good. This was out third time here and the food was delish.
author: Barb B.

description: great sushi!! this place is quite unassuming from the outside. hidden behind a tree, i would never think to walk in. lucky for me and my yelp-wise mind i found this place. the sushi is fresh and really good. the fire roll was my favorite. just enough kick and nothing too flashy. simply yellowtail and salmon in a spicy sauce. mmMmm. i saw some other delicious sounding stuff on their special board including a lobster hand roll. can't wait to come back.
author: Regina C.

description:
Two things that I will rave about this resto;
1.  Very large portions on the combo dinners - Sashimi (about 10 pieces) and teriyaki chicken (4 large pieces with bone in)...enough to feed two people and only $17!  
2.  Teriyaki chicken - must get the fried one...very crispy and light with a teriyaki glaze on top.  Tasty!

Although not the best service...very slow and can barely understand English but were very flexible as they allowed us to substitute the tuna sashimi in our combo meal to hamachi and white tuna.  The sashimi grade wasn't the best but worth the price you pay!  Will definitely be back and will give the sushi a try next time.
author: Tina L.

description:
GREAT sushi for a GREAT price and a quick, friendly service!

    - BIG slices of fish (nigiri)
    - BIG chunks of tofu (miso soup)
    - SAVORY rolls 
            :: space - eel, tuna, yellowtail 
            :: heavenly - spicy tuna, asparagus, green onions

Would definitely go back here again :-)! I liked how they gave out Mellow Kiss  (chocolate cube) instead of mints or orange wedges with the bill.
author: Celeste M.

description:
It's that time of the week..sushi time! When we went there tonight, the places was empty. At first this worried me but I got over it.

Tonight's devour was he fire (spicy yellowtail and salmon), dream (salmon and avocado with eel on top), tanuki roll (fired shrimp roll topped with eggplant and eel), topical (mango avocado, tuna and white tuna), and nasu (eggplant in ponzu marinade). Oh and of course uni and oyster shots! The fish and ingredients down to that tangy ginger were fresh. It was one of those instances where I didn't need soy sauce when I ate piece of raw fish.

There's only 15 or so tables that seat up to 4 people and a sushi bar.  The walls are semi-bright colors with little abstract painting on the wall. It was quiet tonight but during full house I don't think you'd be able to hear your date.

The service was prompt and efficient. The prices for each roll ranges from $6 to $13. They also serve cooked food that i must try next time. 
NOTE: they only take reservations for a big party, i.e. 6 or more.
author: Lola L.

description:
Boats! Sushi BOATS! 

Still fresh. Still Japanese owned. And the side noodle salad makes me salivate at the sheer memory.

If you order teriyaki chicken, be ready to share your plate. It is huge.

The melty kiss candies that come with the check are blissful.
author: Judy L.

description: Fresh Sushi! Good atmosphere. Priced a little high and I have had better, but overall it was an enjoyable sushi run.
author: Shawn O.

description:
Pretty good quality sushi.  Fast service, except for at the very end.  We waited around for a long time hoping to get our check.  Finally we had to ask for it.

I had maguro nigiri, mackrel nigiri, and a heavenly roll.  The heavenly rool was good.  Loved the asparagus inside.  The nigiri was good quality too.
author: Angie C.

description:
I've been here twice in the past week and I have to say that I am a huge fan. 

It's not complicated, what I look for is two things - 1) Quality of food 2) Service. Pretty simple, right? Well, if only more restaurants could get it right like Tanuki!

The first time, I was with a group of four. We had uni shots all around, which were delicious, and I thought the quality of sashimi and sushi rolls was great. But what brought me over to five star quality was service. The waiter/waitress who served and attended us were extremely friendly and helpful. They definitely checked up on us, which is something I'm not even that used to in restaurants anymore. They also kept refilling our tea and letting us sit and chat in the restaurant far after the restaurant had closed..and we didn't even notice, we were so comfortable. Haha, I feel bad - we made them pretty much wait there! But they were so friendly and personable nonetheless.

The other time I came with the bf and became even more of a fan after trying their oyster shots. I like restaurants with certain things that just.. make them special..give them that extra edge and unique personality. With Koo, my fave Japanese restaurant in the city, it's the Spoonfuls of Happiness, with Eiji, it's their amazing mochi, and with Sushi Bistro, it's their tremendous variety of rolls with crazy names. With Tanuki, I love their side menu - oyster shots, uni shots, lobster hand rolls...very nice. I also like the melted chocolate squares they give you at the end of the meal - far better than any gum or candy I've ever gotten on my bill, haha. The prices are honestly comparable and not overly expensive or too cheap - I expected this and have no complaints. The food and service are worth it, after all. 

Overall, I don't give five stars too often but the dining experience was simply wonderful and I will be coming back a lot!
author: Nebula H.

description:
According to many Japanese folks, this restaurant is the best sushi restaurant in the Bay Area. It's definitely authentic and the sushi chefs are generous beyond belief! 

My friend, a regular, introduced me to this spot recently and I was deeply impressed by the quality of their fish and the vast selection. Fresh, superbly cut and and beautifully presented sashimi. Toro, Hamachi, etc etc... Wonderful! The chefs, if they know you well, often offer you items that are not on the menu at no charge. They really hook you up. Mind you, they don't do it for everyone but damn are they generous to their regular customers!

You're not going to find a bunch of speciality rolls and that's the beauty of this restaurant. They focus on fresh high-quality fish...true Japanese style. In this day in age where sushi restaurant are known for  creations such as deep fried jalapeno-cream cheese-tempura shrimp rolls, usually named 'sex in clouds' or something catchy, it's a breath of fresh air to find a simple yet authentic restaurant like Tanuki.

Sitting at the sushi bar is the best, of course, if you're a sushi lover! Make sure to share your sake with the chefs and enjoy everything that this wonderful restaurant has to offer!
author: Susie O.

description: Not sure how this place got 4 stars....Came here with one of my good friends a few days ago and was excited to try this place out. When we came in...there was no server or host/waitress around so we seated ourselves in a table near the window. FYI not a big restaurant, its actually very small. Only 1 sushi chef. I ordered Sake sashimi and a salmon skin roll. My friend ordered uni and some other dish. Was starving since I had not eaten breakfast or lunch...so anyways the food took FOREVER to come. When my sake sashimi (salmon) came...my friend and I looked at it. It was the ugliest sake I have ever seen! half of it was brownish grey...didnt look fresh at all! He ate the uni and said it wasnt fresh either. The salmon skin roll was "okay" ,,,ive had better. The food took forever to come...which was REALLY annoying. I mean how could you have only one sushi chef?? Makes no sense. After eating the sake and salmon skin roll I realized it wasn't enough and requested to get a vegetable tempura roll. Told one of the girl waitress's and 10, 15, 20 min goes by and still no food. The guy server came and asked if everything was ok but I told him that I was waiting on my roll. He seemed confused because apparently there was no order of vegetable tempura!! Basically sat there waiting like a dumbass. I was so irritated and by the time the vegetable tempura actually came it tasted like shit. Worst place ever...service is especially bad. The pics were seriously deceiving....
author: Colette P.

description:
I grew up a few blocks around from Tanuki and still anytime I go home I have to stop by with my family.  The atmosphere is clean and welcoming, and the food is always fresh.

This is definitely one of my favorite places in the city for takeout also!  Check it out :-)
author: Dianna L.

description:
My first time here. My dry cleaner, seamstress across the street recommended it when I asked about Sushi in the neighborhood.
The place is as clean as can be, small and intimate (probably seats no more than 40) and the service was personable and very good. I had the Sashimi Combination which was very nicely presented, fresh and delicious. I will try this place again soon.
author: Lee S.

description: Great service.  Great food. Good price.  Had ours take out, brought it to the dog park 3 blocks away so our pupster could play while we ate!  Beautiful day!
author: Elizabeth C.

description:
Considering it was Valentine's Day, I think the wait was ok, about 15 minutes around 7:30pm. After 8pm there's no wait.

Scallop Lover Roll: delicious, baked with salmon inside and raw scallop outside with a sweet mayo sauce. 
Fire Roll: spicy hamachi and salmon inside, yums.
Dream Roll: Salmon, unagi and avocado, it's good but a pretty normal tasting roll.

Sukiyaki and tuna sashimi combo: Miso soup had big chucks of soft tofu, much appreciated. Noodle salad was dressed in mayo or something, I'm not a fan of mayo but if people like mac salad, it's a similar taste. Sukiyaki was smaller and a little bland compared to other restaurants. The tuna sashimi was pretty fresh. An ok combo overall. I'd go for the sashimi again, but with a different entree.
author: Jocie M.

description: I've been to this restaurant many years ago but haven't been back for a while because I've moved away.  My friend called and asked me to meet her there last Sat and I am glad she did!  We sat at the sushi bar like we always have and were greeted by the friendly sushi chefs including one who is the owner!  We ordered a combination of sushi and sashimi and oh my goodness, everything was soooooo fresh and delicious!  Boy, how I miss this place!!!  I love sushi and I have to say I'm picky at what I eat, especially sushi is one of my favorite food!  We order toro sushi, negitoro, two different kinds of uni, scallop, anago, hamachi, miso soup with clams and mushroom.  The best part was we were having such a good time we were sitting there for quite a while but no one ever came to rush us or try to give us our bill.  The price was also very reasonable!  Two of us was about $100!  I was actually expecting much more.  Can't wait to go back!!!
author: winnie l.

description:
Delicious sushi at a great price.  Came here with a friend the other night for a bite to eat.  The service was quick but they misunderstood our order and brought us non-spicy spicy tuna rolls (yeah, I know).   This could have tainted my experience (because I looooooooove spicy) but the server was so pleasant and polite, I just wanted to hug her.  

Everything tasted very fresh; you can't beat that...especially in San Francisco.
author: Daniela L.

description:
Great little traditional Japanese restaurant, in terms of both food and decor.  I've been to a lot of gaudy Japanese places lately, and it was a breath of fresh air to sit down here to some quality food. 

Agedashi tofu was delicious, and even better and easier to eat than other places' tofu because they fry bite-sized cubes.  The Bamboo roll and sashimi that I sampled were very fresh.  Our okame udon was not fancy but still very good, with perfectly-cooked noodles.

I was stuffed by the end of the meal but not feeling gross, since all the flavors were very light.  Highly recommended for a quiet meal out.
author: S L.

description:
Normally I can hardly contain myself to Yelp a restaurant that's either new to me or recently rediscovered.  But Tanuki, which I've frequented on and off for years, including just a few days ago, has just never pushed my "this is so transplendently good that I'm making up idiotic words like 'transplendent'" button, nor my "this sucks worse than every single bad thing that happened between 1975 and 1982, including senior prom" button.  It's a testament to the strength of my will to procrastinate from work right now that I'm breaking down and reviewing the place. 

Of course, none of this is Tanuki's fault, and hence the four stars.  It's a solid, authentic Japanese restaurant in the inner Richmond.  A great neighborhood restaurant that I wish were closer to my neighborhood.  For years they've consistently served great sushi at reasonable prices, surrounded by an extensive menu of traditional, if not particularly exotic dishes.

A few recommendations:  Rolls are particularly good here, including the Tanuki (fried shrimp, eel, marinated eggplant, and avocado), the Bamboo (white tuna and cucumber, with salmon, green onion, and white tuna topping), and numerous vegetable rolls.  They also do a great hirame nigiri.  In the non-sushi category, the sea bass is succulent and cooked perfectly.  Lots of sake choices, which is great.  And best of all, it's all reasonably priced.

I'll be back at Tanuki again soon, taking its quality and consistency for granted, as I have all along.
author: Hugh B.

description:
A pretty solid sushi place!  It never seems too crowded and the staff is super friendly.  Good neighborhood place with a very nice interior.  They have a nice long list of special rolls - lots of creative stuff.

I am in love with their Tuna Tataki Salad - it's a must.  It's got tons of goodies in it.  We've had everything from their miso soup, to the Udon to the tempura mixed plate (it's huge by the way) to sashimi, sushi and rolls.  Sushi seems very fresh.

We've been twice and the second time the food was a bit off.  But since our first visit was stellar, I think we just hit a bad spot.  We'll def. be back!
author: Tracey E.

description: Disappointing reviews on Yelp. First of all, the service was horrible. They just hand you your drinks and food instead of placing it on your table because they expect you to make room for your food.  The food was definitely not made by true a Japanese chef. So, if you want generic sushi then it's fine going there.
author: Mary L.

description:
This was possibly the best sushi experience I have ever had. So authentic, incredible flavors, fun staff. And for a very reasonable price.

We had the miso soup--the tofu melted in the mouth. The crunchy roll, fried shrimp with minced green onion, had the best flavor. I would go back just for that. Other great things included the fresh fresh fresh crab roll with avocado. And the Japanese pepper stuffed with halibut, battered and fried. Unbelievable. All in all we had three rolls, two soups, a chicken yakatori, and the complimentary halibut-peppers for $40 including tip.

The sushi chef and waitress were as nice as they get. Can't wait to go back.
author: Andrea F.

description:
I'm always excited to find another great sushi place since, let's face it, I'm a sushi addict. Everything here was fantabulous: the fish was fresh and yummy, the staff was friendly, and it's always a good sign to see that most of the patrons are actually Japanese. 

Most notable was the hamachi kama, or grilled yellowtail collar. It was fatty and oily and delicious! Also really good were the dream roll, space roll, and tropical roll. The tokyo roll was also not bad. 

There were 2 downfalls to this place. The first is obvious: the parking sucks! If I'm coming on a weekday from work by bus this downfall would dissappear. The other downfall is that it is expensive! The Chirachi (my favorite!) was $20 bucks whereas most other places it's no more than $13 to $15. And a negihama is $7--more than twice what it is in other good sushi places. The rainbow roll, which I'm happy to report is made with regular crab rather than that tempura crap, is $15!!!! 

This place is really good, but with all of the options for sushi in this great city, I'll keep looking for something both good and affordable.
author: Amy B.

description: Very very terrible experience with this place! I have been to this place twice for lunch with friends, and pretty sure that we are not coming back again. we orderd some nigiri, Sashimi, california roll and some combination lunch sets. one of my friend who order the nigiri luch set only finish half of the order, then refused to finish the rest. The California roll looks cheap and tastes cheap too. Like the one you can get from Walgreen, maybe .........can only satisfy those starving people. sashimi, half is fresh, the other half look old and taste yucky! the combination with fried pork cullet.............not even worth to mention! Never been here for dinner, but after these experiences, i won't even waste one penny at this restaurant again! there are many good japanese restaurants around the city, why here?
author: Jenna G.

description:
I'm glad I took Manabu M's recommendation and gave Tanuki a try when I wanted a change of scenery and some solid sushi.   Sometimes I think to myself, "how different can Sushi really be from place to place?"   It is just fish and rice, right? 
Just a minute off the beaten (Clement) path and parking is available within one block, which is excellent because it is raining.   Small groups and couples sat comfortably and casually in the quiet space.   The sushi chefs greet a customer by name.   
The portions were ample, even large.  We ordered tempura and miso soup to start.  Green tea and a noodle salad were included and BF's miso soup was part of his salmon teriyaki meal.  The miso soup was full of soft tofu. The seaweed salad was larger than at most places - I wasn't able to finish it by myself and I LOVE seaweed salad and I'm SERIOUS about getting my 5 servings of veg per day.   I ordered the special spicy hamachi roll.  Again, large.  Too much for me to eat.  That didn't stop me from tasting BF's salmon teriyaki.  I found it to be a little dry for my taste, but he loved it and the salad that came with it was great. 

There was more food than we were able to eat and the bill came out to ~$45, which I found to be very reasonable for the quality and quantity of sushi.     Next time, I will try the mackerel for sure!
author: Maria C.

description:
They serve the biggest fattest edamame I've ever had.  That alone is worth a trip, plus most everything I've had from the sushi bar is good and the ability to see a TV from most tables is nice.  Food is fresh and place is clean.  Thats all ask of a local sushi joint.

Any restaurant that is able to survive in SF for over 27+ years is impressive.
author: Andrew R.

description: You know you're going to have a great dinner when you go to Tanuki. The fish is extremely fresh and the flavors in the large variety of rolls are soooo good. the servers are attentive and friendly. what more can you ask for? get the saba in any form, you won't regret it. the space and tropical roll are amazing too.
author: Marcia O.

description:
I love Tanuki! The food is great, service is wonderful, and atmosphere is cozy! 

You MUST try the Agedashi Tofu. Agedashi is lightly browned fried tofu with a crunchy shell on the outside and the softest tofu on the inside. The dish is served HOT in a light broth, accompanied by green onion and grated daikon that melts in your mouth. You should definitely eat it first when it is still warm, but be careful not to burn your tongue! =) The proportion is perfect for an appetizer or light snack if you're not too hungry.  

The rolls and other appetizers are also good.  I can't remember what they're called but one of the Sushi rolls with Salmon skin is quite tasty! But all the dishes are all finely-prepared from the green onion toppings to the grated daikon.

I've always received the best service here; but I may be biased bc the restaurant is in love with one of my closest friends that always takes me here. =) But still, the servers are really sweet and the owner is always welcoming to new guests.  

I love the atmosphere! Tanuki is a cozy place with an ambient feel. Very clean and nicely constructed but not too pretentious either. Although Tanuki is across the bay from my neighborhood, it is a nice "neighborhood" restaurant that I will be coming back to, very frequently.

I'd give 5 stars but I'd be biased bc of the special treatment my friend and I receive =)
author: Becka T.

description:
Though more group-friendly than Chin Bistro (located across the street), this sushi joint's service is much more slow and the prices are higher than it's neighborhood competition. 

It took our waitress 15 minutes to even acknowledge our group of 6! It was like we were the elephant in the room that no one wanted to talk about. Helllooo? We're your biggest tip in this restaurant at the moment - make us happy! Plus, she took the order of a couple who came in after us 5 minutes before she hit up our table. Not cool. 

The food was alright. Loved the large chunks of tofu in the miso, great if you like tofu, easy to fish out if you don't!

Sashimi was over-priced, but the rolls were pretty damn good (especially the ones with crab in them - yum!).

Overall, I'll head to Chin for my weekly fix of sushi.
author: Ali L.

description:
Three stars for their rock shrimp, other than that, this place is no big deal. It's not bad, but why go to Tanuki when Chin is right across the street and SOOO much better. 

Now if I could just get Chin to let me bring in some Tanuki rock shrimp I'd be set.
author: stephanie c.

description:
This is a solid 4 star place, FOR SAN FRANCISCO.  Now I have been going here for sometime now and have been reluctant to put together a review.  

This is owned and run by a Japanese fella who treats it like a restaurant in Japan.  He will remember you if you come more than once.   He may even remember your likes and dislikes.  Unlike the joint on Balboa he is not a sushi nazi, but has decent fish. 

Is this the bomtastic sushi, Spanks?  Nope.  It is by all means OK sushi.  Very OK sushi.  But the draw is the price to quality ratio. ON average the cost is about $20 per person.  For the same amount of money at some of SF"s "TOP" sushi places this would be for 1/4 of 1 person. 

OK for Sushi foodies in the area.  For Sushi Nuts like myself with excessively high Sushi standards, it is worth it if you are passing by and happen to be hungry , primarily because the alternatives, Chin sushi and Sushi Boat are absolutley disgusting.

You may want to take note however, that yelpers have granted 4 stars to Chin sushi across the street which is light years below Tanuki in quality.   Yelp is losing its pull with me.
author: Spanky M.

description:
Good sushi option in the neighborhood. It was tough to decide which place to try since there's about 3 places within 10 ft. of each other on this block. Fish was ok, but the vegetable combo and veggie rolls were great. The chefs behind the bar looked like they were having a good time and had a couple shots of sake with the sushi bar dwellers which was fun. 

I like creative, non-traditional rolls, which they had a few of, but nothing too special. The Tokyo roll (salmon, tuna & avocado) roll was average. I did enjoy the straight avocado roll (simple, but very fresh) and the grilled eggplant nigiri - nice presentation and good flavor. 

Ordered a bottle of cold sake, not too sweet and not too dry, which was nice--they have a couple selections with a good range. The sake, two bottles of Asahi, the veggie combo, the avocado roll and Tokyo roll totaled $40 which was definitely reasonable. 

Overall wasn't incredibly wowed by anything here...would probably try the other two places on this block before returning.
author: Kelly R.

description:
These days... I'm not really sure it's fair to revue a sushi place based off one go.  Having fresh, well prepared, sushi consistently should really be the star marking me thinks.  Anyway...

Had some really good sushi here on a MONDAY night (Thanks Nobu K for the Monday night sushi tip!).  The fish was fresh, the chef was Japanese and skilled, and the portions were ample.  Price was about what I would expect, so I wasn't stoked on that, but such is Sushi in the US.  My wife, from Nagoya, was also happy with the sushi... aside from the Jive-Ass roles that I ordered along with our Nigiri.
author: Dan M.

description:
Really...   I've been a fundamentalist zealot to the shrine of Ino Sushi and Kabuto for a long long time.  Both, obviously for different reasons that don't need explanation.  
My girlfirend and I were in search of a new haunt to inhabit...  good fish, mellow atmosphere, low on the pretension scale (read: no gushing over the live scallops)  
Oh... man.  I don't have much time, but need to get the word out...  this is in fact the real deal.  
wonderful, elegant, beautiful, creative without being showy.   
The only downside is the TV in the corner, but I'm in the minority regarding the love of sports, or lack thereof.  

You really should go if you want a lovely, tasty, affordable and casual meal you won't forget.  really.   

As a barometer...  my sushi restaurant loves:
Ino, Kabuto, Atami

My sushi w.t.f. you call this sushi list:
godzilla, godzilla, godzilla, and sushi groove south, as I gave up the house music in my twenties.  I don't go to sushi to hopefully get laid.
author: Peter L.

description:
One of my favorites at this long time Richmond Restaurant is the bowl of spring noodles that they serve as appetizers. I haven't found it served elsewhere in the city. Anyone know the secret ingredients??? I want to know!

Their sushi is pretty fresh and the prices are not cheap but it's a nice splurge once in awhile. I'd go there just to eat the noodles anytime!
author: Mashimaro M.

description:
I am a San Francisco native who has been to many sushi restaurants including Tokyo.

This is THE BEST place in the city for sushi.  
The sushi chef is truly a Master Chef.
HIGHLY RECOMMEND.
This is as good as it gets if you want to have top notch Japanese food.
author: Mike L.

description:
Tanuki - is a relaxing neighborhood sushi joint in the Richmond District. The Hamachi Kama was extremely fresh when it came out - YUM! Sushi Rolls were yummy as well - as well as the Spinach Gomo eh - Menu is pretty extensive especially if you are not in the mood to just have Sushi and Sashimi. Great atmosphere in my opinion especially since you can see the Sushi chefs carve out thier art for you by the bar.

Check it out!
author: Christian S.

description:
This place has been around for a long time.  The service is always friendly and efficient, but the food tends to be inconsistent.  BIG HOWEVER...  We had a GREAT dinner, last Friday. 

Combination dinner (Tempura/Sashimi) perfect tempura; golden, light, and crispy.  Maguro was fresh.

Yosenabe:  Huge portion, that I can never finish... and I'm a real big eater!

Kaki Fried:  Perfectly fried oysters.

If everything was this good, every time, we'd be here every week.  The food can sometimes be a bit mediocre.  We can't figure it out, but I've been coming here since the '80s.  I like the noodle salad that accompanies the dinners.
author: Collin W.

description: Fantastic! Fresh food and a great quiet enviroment!
author: Eddie T.

description:
It was like I was back in Japan in an izakaya. Yummy delicio food and good service. We got a bunch of side plates - chicken karaage ($6.50), kamikaze roll ($7), seafood salad ($13), a special that was deep fried sweet potato and crab (I think - it was something like that), and of course a large beer.

I'm so happy that Tanuki is just a couple of blocks from where I live. It's perfect for those nights that we don't want to cook and we want some good food at a place that feels like home.
author: Wendy B.

description: Total neighborhood sushi spot and it is small. With the TV on the wall it's kind of like sitting at the sushi bar which happens to be in your living room. The one thing that brings me back here time and time again.....lobster hand roll.
author: Nick M.

description: Second sushi place ive been to in the inner richmond, and while it was better than fune ya, it still wasnt great.  The cuts were real messy, just hacked apet the tuna, and the mackeral was still a bit frozen in the center.  The taste wasnt bad, and the rolls were good, but i think i need to keep on looking.
author: Phil J.

description: This is the SPOT!! For the price and what you get........it's worth it!! You can get the same quality in Tokyo and pay double, seriously-no lie! I've lived in Japan most of my life and Japanese food should be made a certain way to me. That's me and my opinion. There's so many Japanese "style" restaurants out here and a lot is really bad. Some places with people in line for some bad tasting stuff. I don't get it. But with Tanuki, I feel like I'm back home with the flavor of the dishes there. I have to admit seeing a table next to me with a couple eating gyoza with soba is kind a strange while I'm eating sashimi. But everything is MADE correctly and the sashimi is great!!
author: Thecreos S.

description:
I still go back to Tanuki since I used to live nearby.  The place is simple, with the Chef and his son making great fresh sushi.  There's a little bar, with an LCD-TV that usually has sports on it.  So it's cool if you're solo and want a nice meal in a relaxing no nonsense place.  The regular meat plates (i.e. chicken teriyaki) are fairly large, so share... 

My favorite is the chef sashimi... It's excellent!
author: Mark K.

description:
This is my mother's FAVORITE Japanese restaurant; she absolutely LOVES their Fried Chicken Teriyaki and will order it each and every time she goes there.  She also ORDERS one to go.  

I went there for the first time today and was happy with what I ordered: Unaju (eel) and a Salmon Skin roll.  The food was tasty.  I enjoyed the meal.  I don't know if I would say it's the best ever, but I was happy with the food and felt the prices were fair.

The service was fine...it wasn't bad service, but it wasn't over the top terrific either.  I did bring my son - who is less than a year old - and unfortunately, they didn't have any high chairs for him to sit in.  If you are bringing your family here, keep that in mind.  They have boosters but no high chairs, not that this is a kid restaurant though.  (I don't know many kids young enough to sit in high chairs and old enough to eat unaju or sashimi).

As far as the parking goes, I have to be honest.  While I know it's generally difficult to find parking anywhere in San Francisco, we were incredibly lucky and found a spot right away...right across the street.

All in all - happy with the meal and wouldn't mind going back.
author: P T.

description:
I really didn't think much of this place until the day I ordered the Nigiri combo. To my surprise, they actually gave me nine, NINE pieces of real sushi. No california roll filler crap. In addition, it came with six tekka maki. Now that's what I'm talking about. And the quality is there too. Even Anzu (much fancier and expensive) didn't do this good (half the plate was california rolls...).
Moving on, the rolls - I don't know, lately I've become very Japanese. They don't seem too appealing. Deep fried with avocado and sauce? That's NOT sushi!!! ...Anyways, the nonsushi dishes haven't caught my attention but I hear it's good. Maybe. I'll stick to my nigiri combo.
author: lisa m.

description:
Tanuki is the Japanese restaurant I've frequently the most in my twelve years living in the Richmond district.  It has been doing business at it's location for over 30 years, and I certainly will continue to do my raw fish eating business there.  Whenever I have guests in town who wish for sushi, I bring them to Tanuki or to Ryoko's, but mainly Tanuki, which we can walk to from my flat.

Aki, the main sushi chef, I've known since the first time I walked into the spot.  He loves baseball, golf, and drinking.  Not as much as the fellow working Oyaji, but nearly as much.  Andre, the other chef, is friendly and mellow.  The older woman in the back, Aki's wife and Andre's mother, is a good izakaya cooking chef.  The table staff are diligent, with the exception of prime dinner time week-ends, when it gets bum rushed by patrons.  Tanuki could use extra help Friday and Saturday nights for sure.

I enjoy their chawan mushi and their grilled squid.  It's always comfort to have a small bowl of the chawan mushi on foggy nights.  Warms the belly nicely.  Sashimi is my preference, and they have good fish here.  They also have good izakaya dishes made in the kitchen behind the bar that aren't necessarily on the menu.  The one favorite item that Tanuki always gets right on are the oyster shots.  They rock my world!  Before I even sit down, I order them up.  To me, it is these little spicy servings in shot glasses that puts Tanuki above the myriad other Japanese restaurants in the Clement St. corridor.  Kanpai to Tanuk's!
author: Roland C.

description:
Our new favorite Japanese lunch place.  We've been searching for a good lunch place since Sushi Tomo on Geary changed.  There are very good lunch combinations.  The Bento boxes come in array of multiple options.  They also have a lunch special with Hamachi-Kama as an option.

It's always refreshing to walk into a Japanese restaurant run by Japanese people.  It's the little things that make all the difference with the food.  The tempura sauce comes with the ground daikon and ginger on the side.  You are lucky to get the daikon at most places.  The sashimi is usually sitting on top of a Shiso leaf instead of a piece of green plastic.   

Great combination of food and value!
author: Mark Y.

description:
Yum.  An unpretentious sushi joint in the Richmond, that has a great variety of dishes (tonkatsu for the bro, seafood udon for me).  We were there on a cold night so I didn't try the sushi, but it was all fresh-looking set out behind the glass, and there were a ton of japanese people there.  That's kinda my benchmark for authentic food-- if you have a bunch of chinese people at a chinese restaurant, it can't be too bad, etc.

My seafood udon came with a ton of seafood-- quite a deal at $9.  The scallops were huge, I was fishing mussels and clams out of the broth continuously, the fish was tender and flaky, and there was crab and shrimp in addition to the usual mushroom and chive garnishes.  I could barely finish the seafood, and had to leave behind some of the udon. The broth was very tasty as well.

The bro's tonkatsu came with a cold noodle salad in addition to the regular veggie salad, which was a nice twist.  I am totally going back here again to try the sushi on a warmer night.
author: Tracy D.

description: I think this place deserves a 5 but it's my first time here and wasn't crazy about my order.  My friend loved her order: veg. tempura roll, miso, other stuff, and she loved it!  I ordered the veggie tempura soba bowl and should have ordered the tempura on the side.  The broth wasn't that flavorful and not vegetarian.  Bummer!  Good rice, great service, beautiful decor.  I'll come back, but many people think fish is vegetarian and I don't.
author: Pat P.

description:
OH GOD this place is good. I just made my Yelp account, so I'm running around Yelping everything I see!

This place is one the THE BEST Japanese places I've ever had.

1. I speak Japanese and my boyfriend is Japanese, so we know Japanese food! This sushi here is so fresh and has such crisp flavors, this place is a no-brainer every time.
2. The head chef and most of the waiting staff ARE Japanese, so this place has a really authentic feel where you can talk in Japanese, each authentic Japanese food, and feel like you're in Tokyo!
3. You've got get the negi hama roll and the hamachikama. Their hamachi is the best I have ever had it, possibly only rivaled by hamachikama in Hawai'i (it's Hawai'i--full of Japanese people and fresh fish, so they know their hamachi).
4. People who review this place and give it a bad review don't know their Japanese food; they want it spicier, saucier, whatever--that is NOT Japanese! Japanese food has crisp, fresh flavors and aromas with subtle, delicate taste. So get with the program! You gotta be able to taste that rice vinegar-ry and sesame seed taste.

GO THERE!
author: Majel B.

description:
Great service and delicious food. 

If you stay away from the chicken teriyaki type meals, you can get some delicious, authentic Japanese food (and to be honest, even the chicken teriyaki is pretty good).
author: Mike K.

description:
I've always enjoyed the simple hospitality of this restaurant considering I'm a native of the Richmond district in SF. 

Service: Tonight the service was excellent with the waiters and waitresses alike being very attentive to our needs.

Ambiance: A small but cozy restaurant ideal for a first date or a local sushi hangout with friends

Food: geoduck sushi, heavenly roll (spicy tuna, asparagus), fried calamari

Each piece of sushi was exceptionally fresh based on the texture and taste of the sushi. Portions are typical of any sushi restaurant with about 2 pieces per order of nigri. The variety of rolls came in bunches of six so go for the rolls to get your more for your money. I'd definitely come back again to try different types of sushi.
author: Andrew T.

description: What a disappointment!  After years of recommending, the lobster sushi did not seem like lobster and sloppily made; the hamachi portion was smaller than the appetizer hamachi we ordered.  We will not go back and neither will our friends.
author: Diana J.

description:
This is hands down one of my favorite Japanese spots in the Bay Area.  There are too many great things to say about this place to list here, but for a start, the staff are awesome and friendly, the sushi is fresh and delicious, and the ambiance is nice and laid back.  My favorite is the saba.
mmmmmmmmmmm............
author: Mackenzie M.

description:
need a delicious monday night sushi dinner?

we ordered a salad, two rolls, a sashimi combo (14pcs), and two uni shots.  the uni shots were amazing.

everything else was very delicious, there was no wait at all (in fact at 930 they closed as we were the last table in the establishment).
author: Ameer N.

description:
Friendly staff, very good raw as well as cooked items, and scores high on the authenticity index, contrary to many of the quasi-Japanese restaurants run by non-Japanese (usually pretending to be Japanese) around here.  Don't get me wrong, you don't have to be Japanese to run a good Japanese restaurant, but I've yet to stumble upon a good, authentic, quality restaurant that isn't.  Your best bet is to just let the chef pick out the best items for you, being sure to specify what you don't like.
I think Koo has great quality, perhaps even better than Tanuki, but their prices and snobbyness take away greatly from the experience.
author: Kevin B.

description:
I really love this place; it's what got me to start appreciating sushi to begin with. The staff is really friendly and it's a great environment plus the food is just great and made well!

It does seem like a small restaurant but when I've gone it's been right after they open at night so service was fast.
author: Rachael E.

description: The best sushi restaurant I have ever patronized.  The sushi chefs often treated me to a free sample of something exotic, which has led to me learning about new menu items that I otherwise wouldn't have tried.
author: JK C.

description: I grew up eating here at least once every two months. . .I come back here so often even after moving out of the neighborhood, the older sushi chef recognizes me.  That's how long this place has been open - the reason?  Awesome Japanese food - fresh fish, big dinner plates, and interesting specials.  My favorites - yes, the noodle salad that comes with dinner, the crab pumpkin tempura, tropical roll, anything sushi.  There's two types of chicken dinners too - chicken karaage and chicken teriyaki.  Choose wisely, as I found out one evening.  It was good nonetheless.  It never seems to be crowded, but that's the charm of the place. . . service is always great, and better with a small crowd.
author: Julie C.

description:
Great.  Terrific, fresh sushi, strong Sake selection, really good entrees, nice friendly service and an enjoyable setting as well.  Plus, the bill will be pretty reasonable too. 

Enjoy - this is a good one as opposed to alot of joints that serve bland California rolls and rubber chicken.
author: T D.

description:
I've been here twice and both experiences have been excellent. The sushi is quite fresh. I haven't had the other things on the menu, so I can't review that. The staff are quite friendly and there's never many people there, even though its small. I'm in this area a lot, so I've found it to be convenient as a local. There's another sushi place across the street, but as I haven't eaten there I can't compare the two. In any case, I definitely recommend Tanuki if you're nearby.

I didn't give it a full five stars both because I'm reserving that for things that blow me away, and because I have had better sushi, just not that often. ;)
author: Kristine H.

description: Pretty good sushi.  I was impressed by the variety of taste and selection of roll choices.  I have to say that it was about 3.5 stars because I was underwhelmed by the wait staff, but I think they sere short-staffed to one person.  Fortunately, the tastiness of the Fire and Tropical rolls nearly made up for it and the Crab and Sweet Pumpkin tempura scored big points.   The Popeye roll was an interesting twist, and arrr, I did feel a little stronger after eating.  All-in-all, the quality of the Hamachi and Toro was great (my baselines for rating sushi restaurants), and the price was very reasonable.  I'm now a fan of the Raccoon Dog... at least, I think that is what Tanuki means in Japanese.
author: Marc G.

description: Fish isn't at all THAT fresh but it's pretty decent otherwise. Really great service. The chef chat with us and gave some complimentary food. I'll return!
author: Bobo V.

description: Although I like Tanuki, I don't think it's the best sushi I've had.  I don't go out of my way to eat here, because the parking is so bad on Clement.  Their sushi is pretty fair, but their sashimi isn't the best.  Decent prices.  Koo on Irving is better.
author: Honey L.

description:
I love sushi and eat at different Japanese place all over the city so I was willing to give this place a try. To sum it up - The sushi and sashimi were great but the dinner entrees we ordered were flat out terrible. I just had chilean sea bass last night and for some reason thought I'd order it again. However, this time it was dry and had a texture similar to rice and not fish when chewing it....strange. I'm guessing the fish was frozen...Yeah, definitely 100% frozen...not good. Also, very small pieces of fish all around the table...Salmon, sea bass and yellowtail. They all looked like half servings. I guess this would have been ok if the fish was nice and fresh but it clearly wasn't. 

Service was slow. There were two waiters for the whole place and every table was filled. This meant no tea, long time for bill etc.

On another note, there was an interesting couple eating here tonight. He was probably a not so attractive 65+ and she was a more attractive 38-40...Pimpin at that age must be tough...cruzing in the Jag with a hottie...Looked like a mail order bride situation...o_O At least that made the evening more interesting than the hardly decent food. Wouldn't go back.
author: Con L.

description:
rumiko, from kappa restaurant, told me about this place. i really liked it. and i'm glad i came here. 

the food was very good. the service was just alright (it could have been better). and the uni shots-omg, i think i'm in love!!! i'll definately be back.
author: B B.

description: I've been to Tanuki three times now and it's been a wonderful experience each time i've gone and i had some great food each time i've gone there. The last time i went which was really recent i had the Uni Hand Roll and it's been the best compared to everywhere else that i have gone to try Uni Handroll. I use to not like Uni but now i cant stop thinking about it everytime i go to a Japanese Restaurant. It's a must try each time i go get Japanese Food. Aside from their Uni Handroll, I also like the tempura that they serve. I dont eat Tempura much but I really like the tempura at this restaurant. So far i have not been disappointed with any of the food i've tried there. I also had their Udon with the tempura. If you like Japanese food it's a must try.
author: Jamie W.

description: Freshest fish I've experienced in the City. Everything is really delicious and the combo dinner boxes are huge. They're a little pricey, but great to share with someone else along with a roll. My only complaint is that you need to check your order when taking out. They've messed up my togo order twice. Both times we got the wrong roll, they were okay, but not what we ordered.
author: Kate S.

description: GREAT sushi.  Fresh rolls, great service.  Try the Bamboo roll or any of the spicy tuna varieties.  Awesome miso with big chunks of tofu and lots of seaweed.  I like the little TV with sports on at the sushi bar.
author: Andrea R.

description: They let us know what fish was fresh when we asked and the food was great. Reasonable prices too. The place seemed to be filled with regulars as the chef knew everyone who walked in (except us, it was our first time).
author: Michael H.

description: This little sushi restaurant is a GEM in the richmond district hidden on california and 6th ave. Been going here for a few years now with my bf who has been going for over 10 years. Lovely sushi rolls [please, do not go here if you're going to order a cucumber roll], especially the lobster hand roll. My favorites are the savory, juicy oyster shooters [no alcohol in these] and chicken teriyaki---but before you think "how unoriginal!", this ain't your usual boneless, skinless chicken teriyaki in a bento box with salad and rice from any japanese restaurant, Tanuki's chicken teriyaki is cut up pieces of delicious fried chicken [GOOD sized pieces with skin and bone-on] with a tasty crispy batter drizzled with teriyaki sauce.
author: kristin e.

description: I don't claim to be a sushi connoisseur or even sushi-adventuresome for that matter, so this modest little secret sushi hideaway is the perfect choice as my favorite sushi spot.  It has a tiny dining room with a microscopic sushi bar behind which work some really mellow, friendly and unpretentious sushi chefs who will treat you very well.  The fish is super fresh, they use real crab and have about 10 different kinds of cold saki on display.
author: Rick H.

description: I've given this place more second chances than you can count. Usually because someone tells me it's great and I say, "That place on Calif?" I go and find out that it's the same Tanuki I've had mediocre experiences at before. Perhaps I've been spoiled by the fantastic Japanese food I've had all over the Bay Area. A friend begged me to try Tanuki A-gain, "It's great man you'll really like it." I went and found that it wasn't great A-gain and I didn't really like it A-gain. The service was tepid. The sushi expensive and forgettable. Pick a direction, drive no more than 2 miles, and I guarantee you'll find better sushi joints. Overall Tanuki....not so much.
author: Johnny C.

description: One of our favorite sushi restaurant and one of the oldest Japanese restaurant in the city.  Excellent sashimi, creative rolls, cozy and small environment, and very friendly sushi chefs.  Tanuki may not be the right place for folks who doesnt explore much beyond "california roll".
author: F B.

description:
I agree with some other posters here...  I've been going here for several years and service has declined just recently.  I hope it's a blip.  Service continues to be very friendly but long waits and forgetting of orders happened several times this weekend, and the place was not crowded!  The food continues to be delicious and fresh, which will make me continue to come back for now!!!  Glad they're here!
They're vegetarian nigiri (yes, I know!) are very delicious.  Among all the other things, but I've never had such good vegetable sushi.  The mushroom and eggplant ones are yummy.
author: R N.

description: I've been a loyal customer of Tanuki for 3 years now, it's my favorite Sushi restaurant in San Francisco.  There's very little to critique about the food as it's extremely fresh and they have the best Uni I've ever had in California.  I would recommend sitting up at the bar as you're sure to have a much more enjoyable dining experience.  The chefs are extremely friendly and love to to share a drink or two or three with customers.  A couple of favorite items besides the fantastic sushi are the Oyster shots and Nameko soup!
author: N E.

description: I have had pretty much everything on the menu here. I live very close to this neighborhood friendly sushi restaurant. I think it is a very good place for a neighborhood restaurant. Occasionally I have had bad sushi but it is one out of 10 times.
author: bora o.

description: This food rocked.  After our initial order, we ordered more rolls late in the game and they seemed to take forever, sort of like how long it took for us to find parking.  Besides the awesome food, also great was a giant amazon woman who had on a short skirt and was strutting around like a runway model.  The two loud girls next to us were annoying, but the girl at the bar had perfume that smelled good.  My wife asked my friend Larry if he would ask her what the perfume was called but she was with two men, and Larry was afraid they would stab him with a chopstick.  Since there was 19 reviews about the food, I figured this depiction of what happened around us would be more interesting...
author: Phil C.

description: This is one of my fave restaurants!  We try to eat here at least once a week.  Uni, scallop lover, hamachi kama & the lobster handroll are must haves.  The sushi chefs are very friendly, although sometimes you have to wait a while to get service because there are only 2 waiters.
author: Connie L.

description: Aki-san is the best! such a friendly environment and the sake is great too.  Place is a local favorite and the food is great! must try environment and try to sit at the bar!
author: Amelia S.

description:
2 1/2 stars

eh, another lackluster sushi experience.  

Went to lunch here today with two friends.  The wait staff was friendly, but didn't understand us when we asked questions or wanted to do some simple substitutions.  They often disappeared into the kitchen for long periods and never offered us water.  The food itself was mediocre, not the best sushi I've had but not the worst.  The fish looked fresh, but overall it really didn't blow my mind.  A friend got the bento box with chicken and beef... her chicken didn't look like anything I would consider chicken.  

This neighborhood has a lot of sushi joints... skip this one and go to Chins Bistro across the street!
author: Ms. M. M.

description: It is always such a slippery slope.  Sometime it is great and other times it is awful.  We had mackerel last night and it was a big hunk and pseudo grisly, but the rolls were great.  Weird right?  I am not sure if sometimes they are just off or if they didn't get a fresh shipment of fish in.  It is neighborhood place, so enter as you will.
author: Nicole F.

description: Very nice experience.  Sushi was fresh and cheap and the service was great.  The only thing I would like to see here is some more wines on the menu.  Otherwise, all else was perfect, I will definetely be back!!!
author: Shannon S.

description:
nice little cozy restaurant not too deep in the richmond, this place has a pleasing atmosphere, friendly staff (to western standards at least), and very fresh fish.

i went here with a friend last night (who doesn't drink so i didn't really get into the sake too much which did keep the bill down) and sat at the bar and ordered the sashimi, uni nigiri, hamachi kama, and a roll with unagi, sake and avocado.  

everything was super fresh but not quite as "melt in your mouth" good as say Eiji.  the uni was sweet, a definite plus...and the hamachi kama was very juicy and tasty.

overall i'd say that for the price (a little over $30 per incl tip) it was great and i'd go back to try more things.  and the friendly service gives this place five stars but Eiji still remains my favorite japanese spot in sf.
author: craig m.

description:
this place was reccommended to me because of its excellent value, and i have to agree.  this is good fish at reasonable prices. and unlike a lot of sushi places in town, they take cash and aren't very crowded.

i'm not sure if i would cross town for this place, but if i am in the neighborhood, its definitely worth it.
author: Steve S.

description:
i have a bias, i admit it.

from working on a movie in this little spot, my co-workers and i have gotten in good with these folks. so when we come to visit, they treat us like old friends, and we have a blast.

but even aside from that, this place is filled to a bursting point with a warm atmosphere stemming from the super friendly, laugh out loud staff. chiko, you got to love her. the food is superb, with very tasty specialty rolls. parking is a breeze too.

kick ass.
author: Darrell L.

description: this is a traditional sushi joint. read: not sushi groove south or tsunami. VERY nice staff, everyone sweet as pie. it felt a bit homey even. good food, however everything had a tendency to taste a bit bitter. (don't ask me why...i never figured it out.) a plus as a neighborhood joint; not a destination.
author: heather m.

description: Solid restaurant. Very fresh fish and attentive service at a pretty reasonable price. Though not  the most original rolls, they were pretty tasty. The clams were a tad overcooked, but overall, I'm a fan.
author: Nora G.

description: Whenever I feel like having Japanese food in the city.  I often headed to Tanuki's.  This place is clean, not too big, yet it is comfortable. The staff here are friendly and the service is excellent. Their sushi are fresh and other dishes are delicious as well.  I like their Sashimi Combination and Marinated grill Sea Bass.
author: Will T.

description: Tanuki has that rare combination of excellent service, relaxed atmosphere and of course kickass food that make it one of the best Japanese places in the city. Unfortunately it isn't the hidden gem that it used to be. Business has really picked up, hooray~
author: insipidphishie P.

description: small-medium sushi bar restaurant....scattering of tables throughout...mix and match configurations to accommodate small to larger groups....fairly quick early weekend evening seating...browsing menu and selecting $nine chilled sake smaller 350ml sizing bottles...ample lower priced sake selection for casual dinner.....menu observing....typical roll selections...dragon, spider, spicy, etc....$four to roughly $ten sushi roll pricing....dinner combinations closer to $twenty total....fried chicken teriyaki and tempura combination....little different....breaded and fried bone-in chicken...smothered in teriyaki...different style, but good....tempura battered lightly and equally good....$seventeen menu price printed for mentioned dinner....a peer's donburi mighty large in appearance....served rice heavy in large noodle bowl....generous layer of eggs, soysauce and tonkatsu....extra-large portion at $ten printed price....portions large at slightly higher pricing understandable....advantage in unique creative twists in menu items...roughly $twenty-five total per person for moderate dinner and drink....
author: Hen A.

description: Went here for dinner last week and everything was super tasty!  The avocado and salmon roll was fantastic, as was the tuna tataki salad.   The sashimi that a friend had looked excellent, as was hubby's grilled octopus.  It wasn't too busy when we arrived (about 8pm) but filled up by the time we left.  Will definitely be going back.
author: Jax L.

description: I've been coming here for years and I just love it. I love how cozy and intimate it is. I love the toro and the rest of the fish here. The quality is topnotch. I love the noodle salad that comes with dinners. Hell, I even love the candy they give out with my enormous bill. I went to japantown to find them - the chocolatemallow things, Milky Kisses I believe.
author: Bruce B.

description: I read the reviews and checked it out with some friends tonight - pretty underwhelmed.  The staff was great - sushi chef was friendly - and the prices are good ($5-7 for most rolls)...  but the sushi didn't come close to Chin Sushi across the street.  I thought it was just average.
author: Ken H.

description: I have been going to Tanuki for over 20 years.  I think they have the best Japanese food in the city.  I LOVE their cold noodle salad.  It's delicious!!!  I usually order the tonkatsu which is tasty, tender and has a cripsy coating which just melts in your mouth.  Their dragon roll sushi is wonderful!  I am not much of a sushi fan, but their dragon roll is outta this world.  If you want to eat high quality Japanese cuisine, try Tanuki!
author: Stephanie A.

description: Another great place to do Omakase.  It's kind of a hole in the wall location-wise and size-wise, but the fish is great, the cuts thick, and the chefs creative. They get especially nice if you bribe them with beer.  The only downside -- it's a bit pricey...dinner came out to $120 for two sushi gluttons with drinks.
author: Eugene F.

description: The sushi here is good, especially for the price.  I had the sushi lunch special and it was only about $10 for plenty of nigiri and sashimi.  Take a look at the "side menu" above the sushi chef for more interesting options like the loberster hand roll, crab and pumpkin tempura, etc.
author: Jared F.

description: Our party of four had to wait a while to receive our menus which gave me time to look around and check out their special menu chalk board where I noticed they serve oyster shooters. My fave! This oyster shot had raw quail egg on top with a tiny slice of lemon. The oyster was super fresh and delicious! The cold noodle salad they serve before your meal I will pass on next time. It has waaaay too much mayo for me and I'm not a hater when it comes to mayonnaise. Their miso soup is killer. I ordered the pork katsu dinner meal and it was tasty, although there was a sufficient amount of fat on the meet. But hey it's pork right? Nice clean restaurant.
author: Ericka A.

description: Fish is fresh and the staff is very friendly.  The person making the sushi is actually Japanese, so you know the food is authentic!  I would say to order rolls and sushi here instead of the boxes, they are much better in comparison!
author: Karina L.

description: Totally acceptably average sushi place, in my opinion.  The fish was fresh, but the rolls weren't very creative and they were small.  It took them a long time to take our initial order, but then again the girls were zooming back and forth from the kitchen so I guess they were just busy.  They happily accomodated our request to modify a tekka roll with some shiso, and the result was actually deliciously tasty.  Sort of loud, though I did like the decor.  I would willingly go back here, but I'd rather find something slightly cheaper - the quality was more in the $5/roll range than the $7/roll.  Nothing special, but definitely solid.
author: Becky N.

description: Tanuki is a hidden gem, I have purposely not yelped about it because I hoped to keep from waiting in line. I love sushi and this restaurant has been the best sushi experience; of my 6 years in San Francisco. The Tanuki roll, WOW, reminds me of Tom Robbins book, Villa Incognito, where Tanuki is kind of a god in a fable where you fill your belly and drink hot tea & Sake while pounding your chest and howling.
author: K M.

description: This place is great! Friendly staff who welcome you like family and good sushi at very fair prices. My husband and I ordered 2 platters of sushi for a party. We brought our own nice serving platters and they created a delicious selection with beautiful presentation.
author: Mishka L.

description: Very authentic Japanese restaurant. The sushi IMO is the freshest in the City. The prices are very reasonable.
author: Gilbert D.

description:
i love to eat crunch rolls and spicy tuna rolls. they are so tasty compared to other Japanese restaurant.
also, nabeyaki udon is my favorite too.
only bad thing is that i spend too much time to look for parking space if i want to go this restaurant.
author: Jane K.

description: so this is my first review straight from my iPhone. If I get frustrated it won't be verbose. Anyway my friends raved about this place and the yelps were good so I was excited to try it last night. I'm not going to sugar coat this, its nowhere near the fish quality of Fuku or Tataki. The place is no frills, which I dont mind.  Hands down get the oyster shot, which I wouldn't have done if not for yelp. Tasty and so creative. We had a couple interesting rolls, and they have a good sake list. The service was really nice too. I'll definitely go back if my friends pick the place, but unfortunately when its up to me this will not be top of the list. Its like any other decent sushi place in SF. There's no shortage.
author: Wendy N.

description: my new favorite japanese place. i had the hankering for ten-zaru soba one day and not many places have it considering most japanese food places are not actually run by japanese people and only have the super americanized japanese food like chicken and beef teriyaki.  and if they do have tenzaru soba, it tastes like crap.  after a series of mishaps (aka-food poisoning from a few chinese and korean owned japanese restaurants), my friend suggested tanuki-as long as i dont get deathly sick and end up puking over a toilet bowl at the end of the night, ill take it.  not only did i not get sick but the place was clean and delicious!  their tenzaru was just like in japan, the noodle salad was something my aunt used to make during the summer, and i love that they have kabocha rolls!!  my new fav is the kaboca crab roll-its to die for.
author: Renee S.

description: This is one of my favorite Sushi places in the city. Completely authentic, not too expensive, not 'trendy' like some other sushi places, and has delicious fresh fish and seafood.  Every sushi roll and sashimi I've tried is absolutely delicious. If anyone hasn't ever enjoyed high quality sushi, this is the place to go. I am always thoroughly impressed, it is well worth the journey over there... It's very reassuring when almost everyone in there is Asian and/or speaking Japanese. Have the green tea ice cream for dessert!
author: Aaron J.

description: One of my favorite Japanese restaurants in the city.  Never had a less than good experience here.  When I don't know where to eat, always up for consideration.
author: Barry A.

description: Eating at a Japanese restaurant that's actually owned by Japanese is a plus.  Don't leave without trying the Cold Noodle Salad, you won't find it anywhere else.
author: Brent N.

description: Wow! this sweet little spot is a really great sushi place--try the Tanuki Roll.  It's their house specialty combo roll that's really unique and tasty.  Parking isn't too bad and we didn't have to wait for a table.  The BF got the Chicken Teriyaki and it came as whole pieces of chicken instead of cut up pieces,  and he was pretty stoked about that.  They staff also gets huge bonus points for quietly tolerating my outspoken girlfriend's graphic accounts of her latest sex ritual.  We'll be back!
author: Sue U.

description: I don't care for sushi. So there. I said it.  I come here for the delicious tempura soba and the fried teryaki chicken. Portions are generous too. The dinners come with miso soup and a glass noodle salad. I like the saki here too. It may be rice wine to you but it's saki to me.
author: chris m.

description:
Fresh sushi and friendly staff.

Never had a bad meal there yet.

Nice homey feel to the place.
author: remy m.

description:
stay away fromthe ankimo and gomae. disgusting.
the uni and oyster shots were alright, but there were shell bits in my uni shot... i mean i can understand if its in the oyster one but in uni...? cant accept that..
expensive n horrible. 
i wouldnt come here again.
author: j s.

description:
Hard choice between 3 and 4 stars.  3.5 would be about right.

Fish quality in general is ok, some things better than others.

The salmon sashimi was defintely smoked, so that is a minus.

The shiro maguro and amaebi were a little past fresh.  Not bad, just a little on mushy side so that the texture made it clear that it wasn't first rate.

The fried onion and garlic roll with shiro maguro was a nice concept that was only marred by the subpar fish mentioned above.  With nice shiro maguro, it would have been a fantastic combination.

The toro was good and the uni was ok.

They do deserve special mention for actually serving katsuo.  It is something a lot of sushi places don't serve, so it was nice to see.  This katsuo was ok quality.

One other thing worth mentioning was that the amount of wasabi served underneath each piece of nigiri varied significantly.  Sometimes it wasn't noticeable, while on other items our eyes were watering due to the large amount of wasabi (and of course it was hard to taste the fish in those cases).

Service was fine.

So, it all sums up to about 3.5 to me, but being forced to choose, I went with 3.
author: Richard P.

description: Very good fresh sushi... gave it 4 stars because of their oyster shots.  A must try.  Sushi chefs are nice, friendly talkative.... nice ambiance.
author: J J.

description: Great neighborhood Sushi. Fresh fish, friendly staff... and really friendly sushi chefs creating delectable rolls and sashimi behind the counter. The sake selection is great too.
author: David G.

description:
Best Sushi in the city!

Fresh and tasty.

Faves = Toro and maguro nigiri, fried white onion and garlic roll, crab and pumpkin tempura, gomea ae (sic?)

Service at lunch can be slower than at dinner, but generally very efficient and nice
author: Bingo T. K.

description: Even though this place is owned by Japanese owner, food is not anthentic.  Service was good.  But price is rather higher than its food quality.   There are a lot more better Japanese restaurant in the City.
author: Michelle O.

description:
Despite this being a hole in the wall neighborhood restaurant I drive up from the South Bay as often as possible to eat at Tanuki.  I've probably eaten at Tanuki twenty times in the past few years and I've never been disappointed.  

The fish is always fresh.  Service is excellent and they make everyone feel welcomed which is nice since it is a small place.  If you aren't a big sushi fan or not culinary adventurous I'd suggest you come to Tanuki and try things you've never had before.  You'll be converted and will discover new and exciting things you never imagined you'd like.

I really don't have any complaints about this place though it would be nice if they accepted American Express cards.
author: Dave H.

description: Everything is awesome here!!! I LOVE their spicy scallop roll and fatty hamachi sushi that are definitely worth to try.
author: nicole t.

description: fresh fish and fun chefs! i love the noodle salad that the meals come with. nom nom..
author: Rosalee C.

description: One could only imagine what to expect from ordering the 'heavenly' roll. Luckily, my imagination was right on par. The spicy tuna and asparagus actually make a tantilizing combination and the tuna was spiced just perfectly! The fish not only tasted fresh, but the quantity was generous. My donburi was not the best I've ever had, especially since there was an excessive amount of sweet teriyaki sauce poured all over my tempura. But maybe I wasn't paying close enough attention to the menu descriptions. My dining companion's soba noodle soup dish was really good and the broth was super tasty. The fact that they stayed open after 9:30pm on a Wednesday night after my yoga class, even though other eateries were closed at this time, makes me even more delighted and thrilled with the overall experience.
author: bloopie s.

description: Super solid.  They have a nigiri combo plate for $20 that is a great value.  You get ten pieces, which includes both obvious ones (tuna, hamachi) and less obvious ones (bonito, aji, clam).  For dinner for two, we gorged on the aforementioned nigiri combination, two rolls (fire and northern -- both good), and a huge bowl of udon.  Oh yeah and a large bottle of Asahi.  FInal bill before tip -- $50.  Not bad for all that.  Overall just a really pleasant experience.  Nice relaxed atmosphere, good service, great food...Tanuki's got it all.
author: Michelle K.

description:
Wow, how can something so good and so close to home pass me by. I usually know the goods around the neighborhood but this place, I had no idea existed.
